buddhist.text: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: it is founded on our thoughts, it is made up of our thoughts. If a man speaks or acts with an evil thought, pain follows him, as the wheel follows the foot of the ox that draws the carriage.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Our very being is shaped by our thoughts. Evil thoughts invariably lead to suffering. This pain follows like a cart's wheel follows the ox's hoof. It highlights the direct, inescapable consequence of negative thinking.

buddhist.text: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: it is founded on our thoughts, it is made up of our thoughts. If a man speaks or acts with a pure thought, happiness follows him, like a shadow that never leaves him.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Conversely, our existence is built upon and formed by our thoughts. Pure thoughts result in happiness. Happiness accompanies the individual like an ever-present shadow. This emphasizes the positive and enduring outcome of mental purity.

buddhist.text: He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me-in those who harbour such thoughts hatred will never cease.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: When individuals dwell on grievances and injustices, harboring such negative thoughts perpetuates animosity. Hatred will perpetually remain within them. This shows how nursing resentments sustains conflict.

buddhist.text: He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me-in those who do not harbour such thoughts hatred will cease.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: If one chooses not to dwell on past wrongs, by releasing thoughts of ill-treatment, hatred will come to an end for them. This suggests that letting go of resentment leads to peace.

buddhist.text: For hatred does not cease by hatred at any time: hatred ceases by love, this is an old rule.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: It is a fundamental principle that hatred cannot be overcome by more hatred. Instead, love is the sole means by which hatred ceases. This wisdom is presented as an enduring old rule, underlining its timeless and universal truth.

buddhist.text: The world does not know that we must all come to an end here-but those who know it, their quarrels cease at once.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Most people are oblivious to the impermanence of life. However, for those who comprehend that all existence here must end, disputes and conflicts immediately cease. This understanding of mortality leads to the cessation of quarrels.

buddhist.text: He who lives looking for pleasures only, his senses uncontrolled, immoderate in his food, idle, and weak, Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) (the tempter) will certainly overthrow him, as the wind throws down a weak tree.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: One who constantly seeks only pleasures, with uncontrolled senses, being unrestrained in eating, lazy, and feeble, is vulnerable. Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion), the tempter, will easily defeat them like a weak tree toppled by the wind.

buddhist.text: He who lives without looking for pleasures, his senses well controlled, moderate in his food, faithful and strong, him Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) will certainly not overthrow, any more than the wind throws down a rocky mountain.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Conversely, one who lives without seeking excessive pleasures, with well-controlled senses, moderate food, and inner strength, cannot be overcome by Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion). They are like a rocky mountain, unmovable by wind, symbolizing steadfastness.

buddhist.text: He who wishes to put on the yellow dress without having cleansed himself from sin, who disregards temperance and truth, is unworthy of the yellow dress.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person desiring to wear the monk's yellow robe, yet who has not purified themselves from sin and neglects temperance and truth, is unworthy. This signifies that outward symbols are meaningless without inner virtue.

buddhist.text: But he who has cleansed himself from sin, is well grounded in all virtues, and regards also temperance and truth, he is indeed worthy of the yellow dress.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The truly deserving wearer of the yellow dress is one purified from sin, firmly established in all virtues, and genuinely upholding temperance and truth. This shows that inner transformation makes one truly worthy.

buddhist.text: They who imagine truth in untruth, and see untruth in truth, never arrive at truth, but follow vain desires.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Individuals who perceive falsehood as truth and truth as untruth have fundamentally flawed understanding. They will, therefore, never reach true understanding and instead pursue empty and futile desires.

buddhist.text: They who know truth in truth, and untruth in untruth, arrive at truth, and follow true desires.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Conversely, those who accurately discern truth from untruth possess a clear and precise perception. Such individuals will indeed attain truth, and their aspirations will align with what is genuine and beneficial.

buddhist.text: As rain breaks through an ill-thatched house, passion will break through an unreflecting mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Just as rain easily penetrates a poorly constructed roof, similarly passion will readily permeate an unreflecting mind, lacking mental defenses. This metaphor illustrates the mind's vulnerability to overwhelming emotions.

buddhist.text: As rain does not break through a well-thatched house, passion will not break through a well-reflecting mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: In contrast, a strongly and well-thatched house resists rain. Likewise, passion cannot penetrate a well-reflecting mind, which is mindful and disciplined. This highlights the protection offered by inner control against desires.

buddhist.text: The evil-doer mourns in this world, and he mourns in the next, he mourns in both. He mourns and suffers when he sees the evil of his own work.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: An individual who performs evil deeds experiences sorrow in this life and also suffers in their next existence, enduring grief in both realms. This mourning and suffering arise from witnessing the consequences of their own harmful actions.

buddhist.text: The virtuous man delights in this world, and he delights in the next, he delights in both. He delights and rejoices, when he sees the purity of his own work.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: In contrast, a virtuous person finds joy in both this world and the next, experiencing delight in both. Their happiness stems from observing the purity and goodness of their own deeds.

buddhist.text: The evil-doer suffers in this world, and he suffers in the next, he suffers in both. He suffers when he thinks of the evil he has done, he suffers more when going on the evil path.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The evil-doer endures suffering in both present and future lives. Their distress arises from reflecting on past wrongdoings. Suffering intensifies as they persist in the evil path. This emphasizes the compounding nature of negative actions.

buddhist.text: The virtuous man is happy in this world, and he is happy in the next, he is happy in both. He is happy when he thinks of the good he has done, he is still more happy when going on the good path.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A virtuous person finds happiness in this life and the next. Their joy comes from contemplating their good deeds. This happiness further increases as they continue on the good path. Illustrating the reinforcing positive cycle of virtuous conduct.

buddhist.text: The thoughtless man, even if he can recite a large portion (of the law), but is not a doer of it, has no share in the priesthood, but is like a cowherd counting the cows of others.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A thoughtless person, despite knowing much scripture, if they fail to practice what they learn, gains no true spiritual share. They are likened to a cowherd merely tallying others' cattle, indicating knowledge without action is spiritually barren.

buddhist.text: The follower of the law, even if he can recite only a small portion (of the law), but, having forsaken passion and hatred and foolishness, possesses true knowledge and serenity of mind, he, caring for nothing in this world or that to come, has indeed a share in the priesthood.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A true follower, even with limited scriptural knowledge, has abandoned passion, hatred, and foolishness. Possessing true knowledge and mental serenity, free from worldly concerns, such a person genuinely participates in the priesthood.

buddhist.text: Earnestness is the path of immortality (Nirvana), thoughtlessness the path of death. Those who are in earnest do not die, those who are thoughtless are as if dead already.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Earnestness is the direct path to immortality, or Nirvana. Conversely, thoughtlessness leads to spiritual death. Those who are earnest truly live and do not die, while the thoughtless are metaphorically already dead.

buddhist.text: Those who are advanced in earnestness, having understood this clearly, delight in earnestness, and rejoice in the knowledge of the Ariyas (the elect).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Individuals who have progressed significantly in earnestness, having clearly grasped its importance, find joy in it. They also delight in the wisdom of the Ariyas, the elect, describing the profound satisfaction from spiritual dedication.

buddhist.text: These wise people, meditative, steady, always possessed of strong powers, attain to Nirvana, the highest happiness.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Wise individuals are meditative, unwavering, and possess strong inner powers. Through these qualities, they are able to achieve Nirvana, which is unequivocally described as the highest form of happiness. This outlines the qualities leading to ultimate liberation.

buddhist.text: If an earnest person has roused himself, if he is not forgetful, if his deeds are pure, if he acts with consideration, if he restrains himself, and lives according to law-then his glory will increase.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: An earnest person who is awakened and remains mindful, whose actions are pure, considerate, and self-controlled, and who lives in harmony with the law, will inevitably see their glory and reputation grow.

buddhist.text: By rousing himself, by earnestness, by restraint and control, the wise man may make for himself an island which no flood can overwhelm.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Through self-arousal, earnestness, and diligent self-control, a wise person can construct an unassailable inner refuge. This spiritual island remains secure against any overwhelming flood, symbolizing unshakeable mental stability amidst life's challenges.

buddhist.text: Fools follow after vanity, men of evil wisdom. The wise man keeps earnestness as his best jewel.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Fools pursue empty vanity and possess misguided understanding. In sharp contrast, the wise individual treasures earnestness and considers it to be their most valuable possession. This highlights the fundamental difference in values between the foolish and the wise.

buddhist.text: Follow not after vanity, nor after the enjoyment of love and lust! He who is earnest and meditative, obtains ample joy.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: One should avoid chasing vanity or indulging in sensual desires. Instead, those who are earnest and devoted to meditation will attain abundant joy and profound contentment. This encourages spiritual focus over fleeting physical pleasures.

buddhist.text: When the learned man drives away vanity by earnestness, he, the wise, climbing the terraced heights of wisdom, looks down upon the fools, serene he looks upon the toiling crowd, as one that stands on a mountain looks down upon them that stand upon the plain.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A learned person, through earnestness, sheds vanity. This wise individual ascends to the pinnacle of wisdom and from this lofty vantage, serenely observes the struggling masses, like a mountain-dweller viewing those on the plain, signifying superior insight.

buddhist.text: Earnest among the thoughtless, awake among the sleepers, the wise man advances like a racer, leaving behind the hack.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The wise person is earnest amidst the heedless and remains awakened while others are asleep in ignorance. Such an individual progresses rapidly, like a swift racer, leaving behind the slow or uninspired, emphasizing their advancement.

buddhist.text: By earnestness did Maghavan (Indra) rise to the lordship of the gods. People praise earnestness, thoughtlessness is always blamed.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Maghavan (Indra) achieved his divine leadership through earnestness. Earnestness is consistently praised by people, while thoughtlessness always incurs blame. This illustrates earnestness as a highly lauded quality leading to elevated status.

buddhist.text: A Bhikshu (mendicant) who delights in earnestness, who looks with fear on thoughtlessness, moves about like fire, burning all his fetters, small or large.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A mendicant who finds joy in earnestness and fears thoughtlessness advances with the intensity of fire, burning away all their attachments, both great and small, leading to complete liberation from bonds.

buddhist.text: A Bhikshu (mendicant) who delights in reflection, who looks with fear on thoughtlessness, cannot fall away (from his perfect state)-he is close upon Nirvana.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A mendicant who enjoys reflection and is wary of thoughtlessness remains steadfast in their perfected state and is incredibly near to attaining Nirvana. This highlights the path to liberation through mindful contemplation.

buddhist.text: As a fletcher makes straight his arrow, a wise man makes straight his trembling and unsteady thought, which is difficult to guard, difficult to hold back.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Just as an arrow-maker straightens a crooked arrow, a wise person similarly disciplines their mind. Our thoughts are naturally trembling, unsteady, and hard to control, emphasizing the constant effort required for mental mastery.

buddhist.text: As a fish taken from his watery home and thrown on dry ground, our thought trembles all over in order to escape the dominion of Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) (the tempter).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Our thoughts, in their yearning for freedom, are like a fish out of water. They struggle intensely, trembling to escape the control of Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion), the tempter, illustrating the mind's deep urge to break free from negative influences.

buddhist.text: It is good to tame the mind, which is difficult to hold in and flighty, rushing wherever it listeth, a tamed mind brings happiness.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: It is profoundly beneficial to tame the mind. The mind is inherently difficult to restrain, restless, and prone to wander. However, a disciplined and tamed mind brings true happiness, underscoring the great reward of mental self-control.

buddhist.text: Let the wise man guard his thoughts, for they are difficult to perceive, very artful, and they rush wherever they list: thoughts well guarded bring happiness.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A wise person should diligently protect their thoughts. Thoughts are subtle, cunning, and tend to roam freely. Nonetheless, well-guarded thoughts lead to happiness, reinforcing the importance of constant vigilance over one's mind.

buddhist.text: Those who bridle their mind which travels far, moves about alone, is without a body, and hides in the chamber (of the heart), will be free from the bonds of Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) (the tempter).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Those who can control their far-ranging, solitary, bodiless mind, even though it is hidden deep within the heart, become free from Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion)'s bonds by restraining this mind. This highlights liberation achieved through deep mental mastery.

buddhist.text: If a man's thoughts are unsteady, if he does not know the true law, if his peace of mind is troubled, his knowledge will never be perfect.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: If a person's thoughts are unstable and they lack understanding of the true law, and if their inner peace is disturbed, then their knowledge will never reach perfection. This indicates that mental stability is crucial for true wisdom.

buddhist.text: If a man's thoughts are not dissipated, if his mind is not perplexed, if he has ceased to think of good or evil, then there is no fear for him while he is watchful.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: When a person's thoughts are focused and their mind is clear, and they have transcended dualistic thinking of good or evil, as long as they remain vigilant, they will experience no fear. This describes a state of profound inner peace and fearlessness.

buddhist.text: Knowing that this body is (fragile) like a jar, and making this thought firm like a fortress, one should attack Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) with the weapon of knowledge, one should watch him when conquered, and should never rest.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Recognizing the body's fragility, like a jar, and holding this thought firmly, one should combat Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) using knowledge as a weapon. Even after defeating the tempter, one must remain vigilant and should never cease in their spiritual efforts.

buddhist.text: Before long, alas! this body will lie on the earth, despised, without understanding, like a useless log.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse reflects on the inevitable impermanence of the body. Soon, this physical form will become lifeless and lie discarded on the earth, despised and devoid of consciousness, like nothing more than a useless, fallen log.

buddhist.text: Whatever a hater may do to a hater, or an enemy to an enemy, a wrongly-directed mind will do us greater mischief.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The harm inflicted by enemies upon each other is far less damaging than the mischief caused by one's own misguided mind. This highlights that internal negativity is more destructive, warning against the self-inflicted harm of uncontrolled thoughts.

buddhist.text: Not a mother, not a father will do so much, nor any other relative, a well-directed mind will do us greater service.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The beneficial actions of a mother, father, or any relative, however great, are surpassed in their service by the profound and positive impact of a well-directed mind. This emphasizes the unparalleled value of mental discipline and virtue.

buddhist.text: Who shall overcome this earth, and the world of Yama (the lord of the departed), and the world of the gods? Who shall find out the plainly shown path of virtue, as a clever man finds out the (right) flower?
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The verse poses questions regarding who can conquer this world and also the realms of Yama (death) and the gods. It asks who can discover the clear path of virtue, comparing it to a clever person finding the correct flower.

buddhist.text: The disciple will overcome the earth, and the world of Yama, and the world of the gods. The disciple will find out the plainly shown path of virtue, as a clever man finds out the (right) flower.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The disciple is the one who will conquer the earth and also overcome the worlds of Yama and the gods. It is the disciple who will discover the plainly shown path of virtue, much like a clever person discerning the correct flower.

buddhist.text: He who knows that this body is like froth, and has learnt that it is as unsubstantial as a mirage, will break the flower-pointed arrow of  (the embodiment of desire and illusion), and never see the king of death.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: One who understands the body's nature as froth or a mirage will shatter Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion)'s (the embodiment of desire and illusion) deceptive arrows and escape the dominion of the king of death. This emphasizes liberation through realizing the impermanence and unreality of phenomena.

buddhist.text: Death carries off a man who is gathering flowers and whose mind is distracted, as a flood carries off a sleeping village.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Death claims individuals who are preoccupied with fleeting pleasures (gathering flowers) and whose minds are distracted from truth, like a sudden, overwhelming flood sweeping away a slumbering village. This warns against heedlessness and attachment to ephemeral enjoyments.

buddhist.text: Death subdues a man who is gathering flowers, and whose mind is distracted, before he is satiated in his pleasures.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Death overtakes individuals who are still absorbed in seeking pleasures and whose minds are uncollected. This occurs before they have fully satisfied their desires, reiterating the unexpected and often premature arrival of death for the pleasure-seeking.

buddhist.text: As the bee collects nectar and departs without injuring the flower, or its colour or scent, so let a sage dwell in his village.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A bee gathers nectar from a flower without causing any harm, leaving the flower's color and scent undisturbed. Similarly, a sage should reside within their community, interacting with the world without causing damage or selfishly exploiting it.

buddhist.text: Not the perversities of others, not their sins of commission or omission, but his own misdeeds and negligences should a sage take notice of.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A true sage should not concern themselves with the faults of others. Instead, their focus must be directed inwards, and a sage should diligently observe and rectify their own misdeeds, emphasizing self-reflection and personal accountability over external criticism.

buddhist.text: Like a beautiful flower, full of colour, but without scent, are the fine but fruitless words of him who does not act accordingly.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Eloquent words that are not supported by corresponding actions are compared to a beautiful flower that lacks scent. Though outwardly attractive, such words are ultimately empty and without real effect or value, emphasizing the importance of integrity between speech and conduct.

buddhist.text: But, like a beautiful flower, full of colour and full of scent, are the fine and fruitful words of him who acts accordingly.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Words that are followed by consistent actions are like a beautiful flower that has both vibrant color and a pleasing scent. Such words are both appealing and effective, bearing positive results and highlighting the power and benefit of aligning one's speech with one's deeds.

buddhist.text: As many kinds of wreaths can be made from a heap of flowers, so many good things may be achieved by a mortal when once he is born.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Just as a variety of garlands can be created from a collection of flowers, so too can a person accomplish many good deeds in their lifetime. This verse signifies the vast potential for positive actions and achievements available to a human being during their existence.

buddhist.text: The scent of flowers does not travel against the wind, nor that of sandal-wood, or of Tagara and Mallika flowers, but the scent of good people travels even against the wind, a good man permeates every place.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The fragrance of ordinary flowers and perfumes only spreads with the wind. However, the reputation of good people travels in all directions, even against the wind, as a virtuous person's positive influence and goodness are recognized and felt everywhere.

buddhist.text: Sandal-wood or Tagara, a lotus-flower, or a Vassiki, among these sorts of perfumes, the perfume of virtue is unsurpassed.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Among all delightful fragrances, such as sandal-wood, Tagara, lotus, or Vassiki, the perfume of virtue is considered the greatest and most excellent. This signifies that moral goodness and righteous conduct hold the highest value, surpassing any physical pleasures.

buddhist.text: Mean is the scent that comes from Tagara and sandal-wood, the perfume of those who possess virtue rises up to the gods as the highest.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The scent of earthly perfumes like Tagara and sandal-wood is insignificant when compared to the fragrance of virtue. The spiritual aroma of those who are truly virtuous ascends to the gods, signifying its supreme quality and recognition.

buddhist.text: Of the people who possess these virtues, who live without thoughtlessness, and who are emancipated through true knowledge, Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion), the tempter, never finds the way.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: For those who embody virtues, live mindfully, and achieve liberation through genuine knowledge, Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) (the tempter) can find no way to influence them. Their emancipation protects them completely from evil temptations and obstacles.

buddhist.text: As on a heap of rubbish cast upon the highway the lily will grow full of sweet perfume and delight, thus the disciple of the truly enlightened Buddha shines forth by his knowledge among those who are ignorant, among the people that walk in darkness.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Just as a beautiful, fragrant lily can grow from a pile of refuse, so too does a disciple of the enlightened Buddha shine brightly. They radiate their wisdom and understanding amidst people who are spiritually ignorant or walking in darkness.

buddhist.text: Long is the night to him who is awake, long is a mile to him who is tired, long is life to those who do not know the true law.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse illustrates how the perception of time is subjective. A night feels endless to someone sleepless, and a mile seems vast to the weary. Similarly, life feels painfully prolonged and meaningless to those who are ignorant of the true spiritual law.

buddhist.text: If a traveller does not meet with one who is his better, or his equal, let him firmly keep to his solitary journey, there is no companionship with those who lack wisdom.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: If one cannot find a travel companion who is superior in wisdom or at least their equal, it is better to continue the journey alone. The verse states there is no true or beneficial companionship to be found with those who lack wisdom, emphasizing the importance of wise association.

buddhist.text: These sons belong to me, and this wealth belongs to me, with such thoughts someone is tormented. He himself does not belong to himself, how much less sons and wealth?
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person is tormented by thoughts of possessing children and wealth, believing them to be their own. The verse points out that one does not even truly own oneself, making the attachment to external things like sons and wealth even more futile and a source of suffering.

buddhist.text: The person who knows his ignorance, is wise at least so far. But one who thinks himself wise, he is called ignorant indeed.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person who recognizes and acknowledges their own ignorance possesses a degree of wisdom. However, one who is actually unwise but believes themselves to be wise is truly ignorant. Self-awareness is crucial for genuine spiritual progress.

buddhist.text: If an ignorant person be associated with a wise man even all his life, he will perceive the truth as little as a spoon perceives the taste of soup.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Even if an ignorant person spends their entire life in the company of a wise person, they will understand truth as little as a spoon tastes soup. This illustrates that knowledge cannot be forced, an ignorant person's closed and unreceptive mind prevents them from internalizing wisdom.

buddhist.text: If an intelligent man be associated for one minute only with a wise man, he will soon perceive the truth, as the tongue perceives the taste of soup.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Conversely, an intelligent person, even when briefly associated with a wise person, will quickly grasp the truth. This is likened to how the tongue immediately senses the taste of soup. It highlights the readiness of a receptive and discerning mind to absorb wisdom.

buddhist.text: Those of little understanding have themselves for their greatest enemies, for they do evil deeds which must bear bitter fruits.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: People who lack understanding are, in essence, their own worst adversaries. This is because their evil actions inevitably lead to painful and negative consequences for themselves. Their own deeds become the source of their suffering.

buddhist.text: Fools of little understanding have themselves for their greatest enemies, for they do evil deeds which must bear bitter fruits.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: People who lack understanding are, in essence, their own worst adversaries. This is because their evil actions inevitably lead to painful and negative consequences for themselves. Their own deeds become the source of their suffering.

buddhist.text: That deed is not well done of which a man must repent, and the reward of which he receives crying and with a tearful face.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A deed is not considered well-performed if it leads to regret and sorrow. If the consequences of an action cause a person to cry and feel remorse, then the act itself was flawed and not truly beneficial.

buddhist.text: No, that deed is well done of which a man does not repent, and the reward of which he receives gladly and cheerfully.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: In contrast, a deed is truly well-done when it leaves no room for regret and the doer experiences joy. The positive outcome of such an action is received with gladness and cheerfulness. This defines a good deed by the positive emotional and mental state it brings.

buddhist.text: As long as the evil deed done does not bear fruit, the fool thinks it is like honey, but when it ripens, then the fool suffers grief.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: An evil deed does not immediately show its full effect, similar to how fresh milk doesn't curdle instantly. Instead, its consequences linger and follow the doer, like a hidden fire smoldering under ashes, eventually revealing its destructive nature.

buddhist.text: Let a fool month after month eat his food (like an ascetic) with the tip of a blade of Kusa grass, yet he is not worth the sixteenth particle of those who have well weighed the law.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Even if a fool practices extreme asceticism, like eating sparingly with a Kusa grass blade monthly, their effort is insignificant. They are not even a tiny fraction as valuable as those who deeply understand and live by spiritual law. This stresses that outward acts without inner wisdom are meaningless.

buddhist.text: An evil deed, like newly-drawn milk, does not turn (suddenly), smouldering, like fire covered by ashes, it follows the fool.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: An evil deed does not immediately show its full effect, similar to how fresh milk doesn't curdle instantly. Instead, its consequences linger and follow the doer, like a hidden fire smoldering under ashes, eventually revealing its destructive nature.

buddhist.text: And when the evil deed, after it has become known, brings sorrow to the fool, then it destroys his bright lot, nay, it cleaves his head.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: When an evil deed's true nature is revealed, it brings profound sorrow to the fool. The consequences destroy their good fortune and even cause extreme suffering, metaphorically 'cleaving their head'.

buddhist.text: Let the fool wish for a false reputation, for precedence among the Bhikshus, for lordship in the convents, for worship among other people!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse describes the misguided desires of a fool, who seeks superficial recognition and power. They might yearn for undeserved fame, a higher rank among mendicants, control in monasteries, or adoration from others. These are external, vain pursuits.

buddhist.text: 'May both the layman and he who has left the world think that this is done by me, may they be subject to me in everything which is to be done or is not to be done,' thus is the mind of the fool, and his desire and pride increase.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A fool's mind is consumed by the desire for control and recognition from everyone, laypeople and renunciants alike. They want others to believe actions are theirs and to be subservient to them. This mindset only fuels their desire and pride, pushing them further from true wisdom.

buddhist.text: 'One is the road that leads to wealth, another the road that leads to Nirvana,' if the Bhikshu, the disciple of Buddha, has learnt this, he will not yearn for honour, he will strive after separation from the world.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse highlights the clear distinction between the path to material wealth and the path to Nirvana (liberation). A Bhikshu (mendicant), being a disciple of Buddha, understands this fundamental difference. Consequently, they will not crave worldly honors but instead strive for detachment from the world.

buddhist.text: If you see an intelligent man who tells you where true treasures are to be found, who shows what is to be avoided, and administers reproofs, follow that wise man, it will be better, not worse, for those who follow him.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: If one encounters an intelligent person who guides to true spiritual wealth, points out what to avoid, and offers correction, they should be followed. Following such a wise individual will lead to improvement and benefit, not detriment, for those who heed their advice.

buddhist.text: Let him admonish, let him teach, let him forbid what is improper!-he will be beloved of the good, by the bad he will be hated.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A wise person should counsel, instruct, and prohibit improper actions. Such a person will be loved by virtuous individuals but disliked by the wicked, as their truthful guidance and moral uprightness challenge wrongdoers.

buddhist.text: Do not have evil-doers for friends, do not have low people for friends: have virtuous people for friends, have for friends the best of men.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse provides clear guidance on choosing companions. It advises avoiding friendships with evil-doers or those of low moral character. Instead, one should seek out virtuous individuals and the best of humanity as friends, aligning oneself with good influence.

buddhist.text: He who drinks in the law lives happily with a serene mind: the sage rejoices always in the law, as preached by the elect (Ariyas).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: One who absorbs and lives by the spiritual law experiences happiness and a tranquil mind. A sage continuously finds joy and delight in this law, especially as it is taught and embodied by the enlightened ones (Ariyas).

buddhist.text: Well-makers lead the water (wherever they like), fletchers bend the arrow, carpenters bend a log of wood, wise people fashion themselves.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse uses analogies to illustrate the concept of self-mastery. Just as skilled craftsmen like well-makers, fletchers, and carpenters shape their materials, wise people actively fashion and discipline themselves. They are masters of their own being and conduct.

buddhist.text: As a solid rock is not shaken by the wind, wise people falter not amidst blame and praise.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Like a strong, unmoving rock that remains firm against the wind, wise individuals remain steadfast and undisturbed. They do not waver or lose their composure, regardless of whether they are subjected to blame or praise from others.

buddhist.text: Wise people, after they have listened to the laws, become serene, like a deep, smooth, and still lake.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: After wise people hear and understand the spiritual laws, their minds become calm and peaceful. Their profound serenity is compared to a deep, smooth, and perfectly still lake, reflecting the inner tranquility achieved through wisdom and understanding.

buddhist.text: Good people walk on whatever befall, the good do not prattle, longing for pleasure, whether touched by happiness or sorrow wise people never appear elated or depressed.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Good people remain steadfast and adaptable through all circumstances, without excessive talk or craving for pleasures. Whether experiencing joy or pain, wise individuals maintain emotional balance, never becoming overly elated or deeply depressed.

buddhist.text: If, whether for his own sake, or for the sake of others, a man wishes neither for a son, nor for wealth, nor for lordship, and if he does not wish for his own success by unfair means, then he is good, wise, and virtuous.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person is considered good, wise, and virtuous if they do not desire a son, wealth, or power, for themselves or others. Furthermore, they do not seek success through unjust or deceptive methods. This describes detachment and integrity as hallmarks of true virtue.

buddhist.text: Few are there among men who arrive at the other shore (become Arhats), the other people here run up and down the shore.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Only a small number of people attain the 'other shore,' which signifies becoming an Arhat (a perfected being free from suffering). Most other people remain on the 'shore,' meaning they are still entangled in worldly existence and the cycles of suffering.

buddhist.text: But those who, when the law has been well preached to them, follow the law, will pass across the dominion of death, however difficult to overcome.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Those who diligently follow the spiritual law, after it has been clearly taught to them, will pass across the dominion of death. This signifies achieving liberation from the cycle of rebirth, even though overcoming death's power is an extremely challenging feat.

buddhist.text: A wise man should leave the dark state (of ordinary life), and follow the bright state (of the Bhikshu). After going from his home to a homeless state, he should in his retirement look for enjoyment where there seemed to be no enjoyment. Leaving all pleasures behind, and calling nothing his own, the wise man should purge himself from all the troubles of the mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A wise person should abandon the ignorant, 'dark' state of ordinary life for the enlightened, 'bright' state of a Bhikshu (mendicant). By becoming homeless and detached, they find joy in spiritual solitude where none seemed to exist. They must renounce all worldly pleasures and possessions to purify their mind from worries.

buddhist.text: A wise man should leave the dark state (of ordinary life), and follow the bright state (of the Bhikshu). After going from his home to a homeless state, he should in his retirement look for enjoyment where there seemed to be no enjoyment. Leaving all pleasures behind, and calling nothing his own, the wise man should purge himself from all the troubles of the mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Same as verse 87, this reinforces the renunciation of worldly life and pleasures as the path to mental purification and spiritual liberation.

buddhist.text: Those whose mind is well grounded in the (seven) elements of knowledge, who without clinging to anything, rejoice in freedom from attachment, whose appetites have been conquered, and who are full of light, are free (even) in this world.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Individuals whose minds are firmly established in the seven elements of knowledge and who find joy in freedom from attachment are truly liberated. They have conquered their desires and are filled with spiritual light, experiencing profound freedom even while living in this world.

buddhist.text: There is no suffering for him who has finished his journey, and abandoned grief, who has freed himself on all sides, and thrown off all fetters.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person who has completed their spiritual journey and abandoned all grief experiences no suffering whatsoever. They have liberated themselves from all attachments and removed all spiritual bonds, achieving a state of complete freedom and profound peace.

buddhist.text: They depart with their thoughts well-collected, they are not happy in their abode, like swans who have left their lake, they leave their house and home.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: These liberated individuals leave their current dwelling with focused and collected thoughts, finding no lasting happiness in their temporary abode. Like swans gracefully leaving their lake, they abandon their worldly houses and homes, symbolizing their complete detachment from material life.

buddhist.text: Men who have no riches, who live on recognised food, who have perceived void and unconditioned freedom (Nirvana), their path is difficult to understand, like that of birds in the air.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Individuals who possess no wealth and subsist on simple, accepted food, yet have understood the emptiness of existence and attained Nirvana, follow a path that is hard to comprehend. Their way of life is as mysterious and untraceable as the flight of birds in the air, invisible to ordinary perception.

buddhist.text: He whose appetites are stilled, who is not absorbed in enjoyment, who has perceived void and unconditioned freedom (Nirvana), his path is difficult to understand, like that of birds in the air.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This describes a person whose desires are calmed and who is not lost in worldly pleasures. Having grasped the concept of emptiness and unconditioned freedom (Nirvana), their spiritual journey is obscure and difficult for others to follow, much like the unseen path of birds in the sky.

buddhist.text: The gods even envy him whose senses, like horses well broken in by the driver, have been subdued, who is free from pride, and free from appetites.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Even the gods envy a person whose senses are fully subdued, like well-trained horses guided by an expert driver. This individual is free from pride and all worldly desires. Such mastery and liberation are considered superior even to heavenly existence.

buddhist.text: Such a one who does his duty is tolerant like the earth, like Indra's bolt, he is like a lake without mud, no new births are in store for him.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person who perfectly performs their duty is tolerant like the vast earth and firm like Indra's bolt. Their mind is pure and undisturbed, like a lake without mud. For such a being, there are no future births, indicating their attainment of liberation.

buddhist.text: His thought is quiet, quiet are his word and deed, when he has obtained freedom by true knowledge, when he has thus become a quiet man.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: When a person achieves freedom through true knowledge, their thoughts, words, and actions become profoundly quiet and peaceful. They have truly become a 'quiet man,' embodying inner serenity that extends to all aspects of their being.

buddhist.text: The man who is free from credulity, but knows the uncreated, who has cut all ties, removed all temptations, renounced all desires, he is the greatest of men.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The greatest among men is one who is free from blind belief, but knows the 'uncreated' (Nirvana). This individual has severed all attachments, overcome all temptations, and renounced all desires, demonstrating ultimate mastery and wisdom.

buddhist.text: In a hamlet or in a forest, in the deep water or on the dry land, wherever venerable persons (Arhanta) dwell, that place is delightful.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Whether in a village, a forest, amidst deep water, or on dry land, any place where venerable persons (Arhanta) reside is considered delightful. This highlights that the presence of enlightened beings imbues any location with a sense of peace and joy.

buddhist.text: Forests are delightful, where the world finds no delight, there the passionless will find delight, for they look not for pleasures.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Forests are inherently delightful places. While ordinary people might not find joy in such solitary or austere settings, those who are free from passions will find delight there. This is because their happiness does not depend on external pleasures.

buddhist.text: Even though a speech be a thousand (of words), but made up of senseless words, one word of sense is better, which if a man hears, he becomes quiet.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Even a long speech of a thousand words, if it is meaningless, holds little value. A single word of wisdom or truth is far better, for when a person hears it, they find inner peace and quietude. This prioritizes quality and meaning over quantity.

buddhist.text: Even though a Gatha (poem) be a thousand (of words), but made up of senseless words, one word of a Gatha is better, which if a man hears, he becomes quiet.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Similar to a speech, a poem (Gatha) of a thousand senseless words is of little worth. However, one meaningful word from a Gatha is superior, as it can bring peace and quiet to the listener. This reiterates the power of concise truth.

buddhist.text: Though a man recite a hundred Gathas made up of senseless words, one word of the law is better, which if a man hears, he becomes quiet.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Even reciting a hundred poems composed of meaningless words is not as valuable as a single word from the spiritual law. If a person truly hears and comprehends that one word of the law, they will find peace and quiet. This emphasizes the supremacy of spiritual truth over mere recitation.

buddhist.text: If one man conquer in battle a thousand times thousand men, and if another conquer himself, he is the greatest of conquerors.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse makes a powerful comparison: if one person defeats millions in battle, while another conquers themselves, the latter is the greatest of all conquerors. It highlights that mastery over one's inner self is far more significant than external military victories.

buddhist.text: One's own self conquered is better than all other people, not even a god, a Gandharva, not Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) with Brahman could change into defeat the victory of a man who has vanquished himself, and always lives under restraint.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Conquering one's own self is superior to conquering all other people. The victory of a person who has vanquished themselves and lives with constant self-restraint cannot be turned into defeat, not even by gods, spirits (Gandharvas), Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) (the tempter), or even Brahman.

buddhist.text: One's own self conquered is better than all other people, not even a god, a Gandharva, not Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) with Brahman could change into defeat the victory of a man who has vanquished himself, and always lives under restraint.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Same as verse 104. This repetition reinforces that self-mastery grants a form of victory that no divine or external force can undo.

buddhist.text: If a man for a hundred years worship Agni (fire) in the forest, and if he but for one moment pay homage to a man whose soul is grounded (in true knowledge), better is that homage than sacrifice for a hundred years.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: If a man worships the sacred fire (Agni) in the forest for a hundred years, a single moment of homage to a person grounded in true knowledge is still better. This underscores the profound value of respecting spiritual wisdom over prolonged religious rites.

buddhist.text: Whatever a man sacrifice in this world as an offering or as an oblation for a whole year in order to gain merit, the whole of it is not worth a quarter (a farthing), reverence shown to the righteous is better.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Any amount of sacrifice or offering made for an entire year to gain merit is insignificant, not even worth a small fraction. Reverence shown to righteous individuals is far superior and yields greater spiritual benefit.

buddhist.text: He who always greets and constantly reveres the aged, four things will increase to him, viz. life, beauty, happiness, power.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person who consistently greets and reveres the elderly will experience an increase in four things: life (longevity), beauty, happiness, and power. This highlights the benefits of showing respect and honor to elders.

buddhist.text: But he who lives a hundred years, vicious and unrestrained, a life of one day is better if a man is virtuous and reflecting.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A life of one day, lived virtuously and with reflection, is superior to a hundred years lived viciously and without restraint. This emphasizes that the quality of life, determined by virtue and thoughtfulness, is far more important than its mere length.

buddhist.text: And he who lives a hundred years, ignorant and unrestrained, a life of one day is better if a man is wise and reflecting.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A single day lived wisely and reflectively is better than a hundred years lived in ignorance and without discipline. This reinforces the idea that true value lies in wisdom and self-awareness, not merely in the duration of existence.

buddhist.text: And he who lives a hundred years, idle and weak, a life of one day is better if a man has attained firm strength.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A life of one day, lived with firm spiritual strength, is better than a hundred years spent in idleness and weakness. This promotes the cultivation of inner resolve and vigor over a prolonged but unproductive existence.

buddhist.text: And he who lives a hundred years, not seeing beginning and end, a life of one day is better if a man sees beginning and end.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A single day lived with the understanding of 'beginning and end' (cause and effect, or the cycle of existence) is better than a hundred years lived without such insight. This highlights the superiority of profound wisdom and clear perception of reality.

buddhist.text: And he who lives a hundred years, not seeing the immortal place, a life of one day is better if a man sees the immortal place.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A single day spent seeing or understanding the 'immortal place' (Nirvana) is superior to a hundred years lived without that realization. This emphasizes the ultimate value of attaining insight into the timeless and deathless state of liberation.

buddhist.text: And he who lives a hundred years, not seeing the highest law, a life of one day is better if a man sees the highest law.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A life of one day, if one sees and comprehends the 'highest law' (Dharma), is better than a hundred years without such understanding. This verse underscores the paramount importance of recognizing and living by the supreme spiritual truth.

buddhist.text: If a man would hasten towards the good, he should keep his thought away from evil, if a man does what is good slothfully, his mind delights in evil.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: To pursue good earnestly, one must actively keep their thoughts away from evil. If a person performs good deeds lazily or half-heartedly, their mind tends to find pleasure in evil. This highlights the need for vigilance and earnestness in cultivating virtue.

buddhist.text: If a man commits a sin, let him not do it again, let him not delight in sin: pain is the outcome of evil.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: If a person commits a sin, they should not repeat it and not find delight in it. This is because pain and suffering are the inevitable consequences of evil actions. It emphasizes the importance of immediate repentance and cessation of wrongdoing.

buddhist.text: If a man does what is good, let him do it again, let him delight in it: happiness is the outcome of good.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Conversely, if a person does what is good, they should continue doing it and take delight in it. This is because happiness and positive outcomes are the natural result of good deeds. It encourages the cultivation and enjoyment of virtuous actions.

buddhist.text: Even an evil-doer sees happiness as long as his evil deed has not ripened, but when his evil deed has ripened, then does the evil-doer see evil.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: An evil-doer may experience temporary happiness or freedom from immediate consequences as long as their evil deed has not yet borne its fruit. However, once the evil deed matures and its results manifest, the doer will inevitably face suffering.

buddhist.text: Even a good man sees evil days, as long as his good deed has not ripened, but when his good deed has ripened, then does the good man see happy days.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A good person may encounter difficult times as long as their good deeds have not yet yielded their full results. But once their virtuous actions ripen, the good person will experience happy and prosperous days. This affirms the delayed but certain effect of good karma.

buddhist.text: Let no man think lightly of evil, saying in his heart, It will not come nigh unto me. Even by the falling of water-drops a water-pot is filled, the fool becomes full of evil, even if he gather it little by little.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: No one should dismiss evil as insignificant, thinking it won't affect them. Just as a water-pot is filled by a continuous trickle of water-drops, a fool accumulates a full measure of evil, even by committing small misdeeds little by little.

buddhist.text: Let no man think lightly of good, saying in his heart, It will not come nigh unto me. Even by the falling of water-drops a water-pot is filled, the wise man becomes full of good, even if he gather it little by little.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Similarly, no one should dismiss good as insignificant, thinking it won't yield much. Just as a water-pot is filled by a continuous trickle of water-drops, a wise man accumulates a full measure of good, even by gathering it little by little.

buddhist.text: Let a man avoid evil deeds, as a merchant, if he has few companions and carries much wealth, avoids a dangerous road, as a man who loves life avoids poison.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person should avoid evil deeds as carefully as a merchant with few companions and much wealth avoids a dangerous road. They should shun evil just as a person who cherishes life avoids poison, understanding its inherent danger and harm.

buddhist.text: He who has no wound on his hand, may touch poison with his hand, poison does not affect one who has no wound, nor is there evil for one who does not commit evil.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Someone with no wound on their hand can safely touch poison, as it will not affect them. In the same way, evil does not affect one who does not commit evil. This illustrates that purity of action provides protection from negative consequences.

buddhist.text: If a man offend a harmless, pure, and innocent person, the evil falls back upon that fool, like light dust thrown up against the wind.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: If someone offends a person who is harmless, pure, and innocent, the negative consequences (evil) will boomerang back onto the aggressor. It is likened to light dust thrown against the wind, which inevitably returns to the one who threw it, causing self-harm.

buddhist.text: Some people are born again, evil-doers go to hell, righteous people go to heaven, those who are free from all worldly desires attain Nirvana.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse outlines different spiritual destinations: some individuals are reborn (in the cycle of existence). Evil-doers descend to hell, while righteous people ascend to heaven. However, those who are completely free from all worldly desires ultimately attain Nirvana.

buddhist.text: Not in the sky, not in the midst of the sea, not if we enter into the clefts of the mountains, is there known a spot in the whole world where a man might be freed from an evil deed.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: There is no place in the entire worldnot in the sky, deep in the sea, nor hidden in mountain cleftswhere a person can escape the consequences of an evil deed. This emphasizes the universality and inescapability of karmic retribution.

buddhist.text: Not in the sky, not in the midst of the sea, not if we enter into the clefts of the mountains, is there known a spot in the whole world where death could not overcome (the mortal).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Similarly, there is no place in the entire worldnot in the sky, deep in the sea, nor hidden in mountain cleftswhere death cannot overcome a mortal being. This highlights the universality and inevitability of death for all living beings.

buddhist.text: All men tremble at punishment, all men fear death, remember that you are like unto them, and do not kill, nor cause slaughter.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: All people tremble at the thought of punishment and fear death. Therefore, one should remember that others are like oneself in their desire for life and aversion to suffering. This understanding should lead to the principle of not killing or causing slaughter.

buddhist.text: All men tremble at punishment, all men love life, remember that thou art like unto them, and do not kill, nor cause slaughter.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse reiterates that all beings tremble at punishment and cherish life. By recognizing this shared desire for happiness and aversion to suffering, one should refrain from killing or causing any harm to others. It is a plea for empathy and non-violence.

buddhist.text: He who seeking his own happiness punishes or kills beings who also long for happiness, will not find happiness after death.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person who, in pursuit of their own happiness, punishes or kills other beings who also desire happiness, will not attain happiness after death. This emphasizes the principle of karma, where actions motivated by self-interest and harm to others lead to negative future consequences.

buddhist.text: He who seeking his own happiness does not punish or kill beings who also long for happiness, will find happiness after death.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Conversely, a person who, in seeking their own happiness, refrains from punishing or killing other beings who also desire happiness, will indeed find happiness after death. This highlights that compassionate and non-violent actions lead to positive karmic results and future well-being.

buddhist.text: Do not speak harshly to anybody, those who are spoken to will answer thee in the same way. Angry speech is painful, blows for blows will touch thee.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: One should refrain from speaking harshly to anyone, because such words will likely be returned in kind. Angry speech brings pain, and physical retaliation (blows for blows) will also be experienced. This advocates for gentle communication to avoid conflict.

buddhist.text: If, like a shattered metal plate (gong), thou utter not, then thou hast reached Nirvana, contention is not known to thee.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: If one remains silent and unreactive, like a shattered metal plate that no longer resonates, they have approached Nirvana. In such a state, contention and conflict are unknown to them. This points to the peace found in non-engagement and inner stillness.

buddhist.text: As a cowherd with his staff drives his cows into the stable, so do Age and Death drive the life of men.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Just as a cowherd guides his cows into the stable with a staff, so too do Age and Death relentlessly drive the lives of human beings. This illustrates the inevitable and forceful progression of time, leading all mortals towards their end.

buddhist.text: A fool does not know when he commits his evil deeds: but the wicked man burns by his own deeds, as if burnt by fire.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A fool may be unaware of the harm they cause when committing evil deeds. However, the wicked person ultimately suffers intensely from their own actions, as if being burned by fire. This emphasizes the self-destructive nature of evil.

buddhist.text: He who inflicts pain on innocent and harmless persons, will soon come to one of these ten states:
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person who causes suffering to innocent and harmless individuals will swiftly face severe consequences. They will soon fall into one of ten specific undesirable states.

buddhist.text: He will have cruel suffering, loss, injury of the body, heavy affliction, or loss of mind,
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The first set of consequences for inflicting pain includes cruel suffering, significant losses, physical injury, severe distress, or the loss of mental faculties. These are direct and painful repercussions for malicious actions.

buddhist.text: Or a misfortune coming from the king, or a fearful accusation, or loss of relations, or destruction of treasures,
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Further consequences include misfortune inflicted by authority (the king), a dreadful accusation, the loss of family members, or the destruction of one's accumulated wealth. These highlight various forms of external hardship.

buddhist.text: Or lightning-fire will burn his houses, and when his body is destroyed, the fool will go to hell.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The ultimate consequences also include natural disasters like lightning setting one's houses ablaze. Furthermore, after the destruction of their physical body, the fool who inflicted pain will descend to hell.

buddhist.text: Not nakedness, not platted hair, not dirt, not fasting, or lying on the earth, not rubbing with dust, not sitting motionless, can purify a mortal who has not overcome desires.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: External ascetic practices alonesuch as nakedness, matted hair, dirt, fasting, lying on the ground, rubbing with dust, or sitting motionlesscannot purify a person who has not conquered their desires. True purification comes from within, through overcoming internal cravings.

buddhist.text: He who, though dressed in fine apparel, exercises tranquillity, is quiet, subdued, restrained, chaste, and has ceased to find fault with all other beings, he indeed is a Brahmana, an ascetic (sramana), a friar (bhikshu).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A true spiritual person, whether dressed finely or simply, is characterized by tranquility, quietness, self-control, restraint, chastity, and refraining from finding fault with others. Such a person is worthy of being called a Brahmana, an ascetic (sramana), or a friar (bhikshu).

buddhist.text: Is there in this world any man so restrained by humility that he does not mind reproof, as a well-trained horse the whip?
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse poses a question about profound humility and self-control: Is there anyone in the world so disciplined by humility that they do not mind receiving reproof, much like a well-trained horse calmly responds to the whip?

buddhist.text: Like a well-trained horse when touched by the whip, be ye active and lively, and by faith, by virtue, by energy, by meditation, by discernment of the law you will overcome this great pain (of reproof), perfect in knowledge and in behaviour, and never forgetful.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Like a disciplined horse responding to the whip, one should be active and energetic. Through faith, virtue, energy, meditation, and discernment of the law, one can overcome the pain of reproof. This leads to being perfect in knowledge and behavior, and always mindful.

buddhist.text: Well-makers lead the water (wherever they like), fletchers bend the arrow, carpenters bend a log of wood, good people fashion themselves.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse repeats an earlier analogy to emphasize self-mastery. Just as skilled craftsmen like well-makers guide water, fletchers straighten arrows, and carpenters shape wood, so too do good people actively fashion and discipline themselves. They are their own architects of virtue.

buddhist.text: How is there laughter, how is there joy, as this world is always burning? Why do you not seek a light, ye who are surrounded by darkness?
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse questions the pursuit of fleeting joy in a world that is constantly 'burning' (with suffering, decay, and passion). It urges those surrounded by spiritual darkness to seek enlightenment or 'a light'.

buddhist.text: Look at this dressed-up lump, covered with wounds, joined together, sickly, full of many thoughts, which has no strength, no hold!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse invites contemplation on the body: a fragile, wounded, impermanent vessel, full of restless thoughts. It serves as a reminder of the body's vulnerability and the need to transcend attachment to it.

buddhist.text: This body is wasted, full of sickness, and frail, this heap of corruption breaks to pieces, life indeed ends in death.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The body, being weak and filled with sickness, eventually deteriorates and dies. It is a temporary heap that breaks apart, highlighting the impermanence of physical existence and the certainty of death.

buddhist.text: Those white bones, like gourds thrown away in the autumn, what pleasure is there in looking at them?
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The verse paints a vivid image of white bones discarded like autumn gourds, asking what joy or beauty can be found in them. It's a reflection on mortality and the folly of being attached to physical form.

buddhist.text: After a stronghold has been made of the bones, it is plastered over with flesh and blood, and there dwell in it old age and death, pride and deceit.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The body is likened to a fortress built of bones and covered in flesh and blood, but it ultimately houses aging, death, pride, and deceit. This illustrates the deceptive nature of the human form, which hides inevitable suffering.

buddhist.text: The brilliant chariots of kings are destroyed, the body also approaches destruction, but the virtue of good people never approaches destruction,thus do the good say to the good.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Even royal chariots decay, and so does the human body. But the virtue of good individuals remains indestructible. The wise understand that only moral character endures beyond physical ruin.

buddhist.text: A man who has learnt little, grows old like an ox, his flesh grows, but his knowledge does not grow.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person who acquires little knowledge grows old in body, but not in wisdomlike an ox that gains flesh but not understanding. This warns against living without intellectual or spiritual development.

buddhist.text: Through many a birth I wandered in samsara, seeking, but not finding, the builder of this house. Sorrowful is repeated birth.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Buddha recalls wandering through countless rebirths in search of the 'house-builder'the cause of suffering. This verse expresses the deep sorrow and exhaustion of samsara (the cycle of rebirth).

buddhist.text: O house-builder! thou art seen. Thou shalt build no house again. All thy rafters are broken, thy ridge-pole is sundered, the mind, approaching the eternal (visankhara), has attained to the extinction of all desires.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Upon enlightenment, the Buddha declares that he has found the 'house-builder' (craving or ignorance) and destroyed his ability to build again. With the mind free and desire extinguished, the cycle of rebirth is broken.

buddhist.text: Men who have not exerted themselves while they were young, and have become weak, like old herons in a pond without fish, they lie sighing over the past.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Those who waste their youth without effort or growth end up old and powerless, like herons in a dry pond. In old age, they mourn lost time, regretting a life not well lived.

buddhist.text: Men who have not observed proper discipline, and have not gained wealth in their youth, perish like old, broken bows, sighing after the past.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: People who fail to cultivate discipline or secure stability in youth decay like broken bows, lamenting missed opportunities. This is a call to live with purpose and foresight.

buddhist.text: If a man hold himself dear, let him watch himself carefully, during one at least out of the three watches a wise man should be watchful.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: If someone values their life, they must be vigilant in observing themselves. At the very least, a wise person should be mindful during one of the three periods (watches) of the night. This promotes self-awareness and mindfulness.

buddhist.text: Let each man direct himself first to what is proper, then let him teach others, thus a wise man will not suffer.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A wise person begins by mastering themselves and doing what is right before instructing others. This ensures that their guidance is genuine and prevents personal downfall due to hypocrisy.

buddhist.text: If a man make himself as he teaches others to be, then being himself well subdued, he may subdue (others), one's own self is indeed difficult to subdue.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: One must live by the teachings they offer to others. Only by mastering oneselfa truly difficult taskcan a person rightly influence others. This highlights integrity and the challenge of self-discipline.

buddhist.text: Self is the lord of self, who else could be the lord? With self well subdued, a man finds a lord such as few can find.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: You are your own master, no one else can truly govern your actions. By mastering yourself, you attain a powerful mastery few others achieve. This verse emphasizes personal responsibility and inner sovereignty.

buddhist.text: The evil done by oneself, self-born, self-created, crushes the foolish, as a diamond breaks a precious stone.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Evil actions, created by oneself, ultimately destroy the doer, especially the foolish. Like a diamond shattering a gem, the consequences of one's own evil are harsh and inescapable.

buddhist.text: He whose wickedness is very great brings himself down to that state where his enemy wishes him to be, as a creeper does with the tree which it surrounds.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person overwhelmed by wickedness ultimately brings themselves to ruinexactly where their enemies wish them to bejust as a creeping vine strangles and brings down the tree it clings to.

buddhist.text: Bad deeds, and deeds hurtful to ourselves, are easy to do, what is beneficial and good, that is very difficult to do.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Harmful and unwholesome actions are easy and tempting, while beneficial and virtuous actions require effort and discipline. This verse reflects the natural difficulty of walking the righteous path.

buddhist.text: The foolish man who scorns the rule of the venerable (Arahat), of the elect (Ariya), of the virtuous, and follows false doctrine, he bears fruit to his own destruction.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A fool who rejects the guidance of the noble, enlightened, and virtuousand instead follows false teachingsultimately harms only himself. Such delusion leads to self-destruction.

buddhist.text: By oneself the evil is done, by oneself one suffers, by oneself evil is left undone, by oneself one is purified. Purity and impurity belong to oneself, no one can purify another.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Each person is responsible for their own actions and their consequences. Only you can purify or corrupt yourselfno one else can do it for you. This is a declaration of personal accountability and empowerment.

buddhist.text: Let no one forget his own duty for the sake of another's, however great, let a man, after he has discerned his own duty, be always attentive to his duty.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: One should not neglect their personal duty, even if another's seems more significant. Once a person understands their own path, they should remain focused on it. This teaches self-alignment and perseverance.

buddhist.text: Do not follow the evil law! Do not live on in thoughtlessness! Do not follow false doctrine! Be not a friend of the world.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse warns against following corrupt paths, living without mindfulness, embracing false beliefs, or becoming too attached to worldly concerns. It encourages a mindful and detached spiritual life.

buddhist.text: Rouse thyself! do not be idle! Follow the law of virtue! The virtuous rests in bliss in this world and in the next.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This is a call to action: awaken and practice virtue diligently. Those who live virtuously enjoy peace both in this life and beyond, reaping the rewards of a righteous life.

buddhist.text: Follow the law of virtue, do not follow that of sin. The virtuous rests in bliss in this world and in the next.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Reinforcing the previous message, this verse urges commitment to virtue and avoidance of sin. Righteous living brings joy in both present and future realms.

buddhist.text: Look upon the world as a bubble, look on it as a mirage: the king of death does not see him who thus looks down upon the world.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: See the world as transient and illusory, like a bubble or mirage. Such perception protects one from attachment, and metaphorically, from the grasp of death.

buddhist.text: Come, look at this glittering world, like unto a royal chariot, the foolish are immersed in it, but the wise do not touch it.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The world dazzles like a royal chariot, drawing in the foolish with its allure. But the wise remain detached, knowing its pleasures are fleeting and deceptive.

buddhist.text: He who formerly was reckless and afterwards became sober, brightens up this world, like the moon when freed from clouds.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person who once lived carelessly but later finds wisdom brings light and hope to the worldjust as the moon shines brightly once it breaks free from clouds.

buddhist.text: He whose evil deeds are covered by good deeds, brightens up this world, like the moon when freed from clouds.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: When someone redeems their past misdeeds with good actions, they illuminate the world like the moon emerging from behind clouds. Redemption through goodness is possible.

buddhist.text: This world is dark, few only can see here, a few only go to heaven, like birds escaped from the net.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The world is a place of spiritual darkness, and few are those who truly understand or escape its snares. Like rare birds escaping a net, only a few reach enlightenment.

buddhist.text: The swans go on the path of the sun, they go through the air by means of their miraculous power, the wise are led out of this world, when they have conquered Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) (the embodiment of desire and illusion) and his train.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Just as swans follow the sun's path and soar miraculously, the wise transcend this world by overcoming Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) (the embodiment of desire and illusion) and all its temptations.

buddhist.text: If a man has transgressed one law, and speaks lies, and scoffs at another world, there is no evil he will not do.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person who breaks moral laws, lies, and denies the existence of a higher realm becomes capable of committing any evil. This warns against moral and spiritual corruption.

buddhist.text: The uncharitable do not go to the world of the gods, fools only do not praise liberality, the wise man rejoices in giving, and through that becomes blessed in the other world.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Those who are uncharitable are denied heavenly realms. Only fools fail to value generosity, while the wise find joy in givingand are rewarded both in this life and beyond.

buddhist.text: Better than sovereignty over the earth, better than going to heaven, better than lordship over all worlds, is the reward of the first step in holiness.
buddhist.author: Buddha
