buddhist.explanation: Even the very first step toward spiritual enlightenment surpasses all worldly power and divine rewards. This underscores the incomparable value of spiritual progress.

buddhist.text: He whose conquest is not turned back, and whose conquest no one in the world can take away, that wise man, among gods and men, is truly called a conqueror.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: True victory lies in irreversible spiritual conquest. The wise who achieve this state cannot be undone by anyone and are regarded as true conquerors among all beings.

buddhist.text: Whosoever has overcome all sensual desires, whether small or great, he is called a man who has subdued all pain, he is truly wise.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: One who has freed themselves from all cravingsno matter how minorhas also conquered suffering. This person is truly wise and at peace.

buddhist.text: A man who is meditative, whose thoughts are calm, who delights in the quiet of renunciation, such a man is free from fear and sin.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A contemplative soul, grounded in inner peace and the joy of detachment, is beyond the grip of fear and wrongdoing.

buddhist.text: When a man has seen the truth, he is not content with mere words or rituals. He lives in direct knowledge and is not attached to rites.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: True wisdom leads one to direct experience. Such a person is no longer satisfied with superficial rituals or empty doctrine.

buddhist.text: To avoid all evil, to cultivate good, and to cleanse one's mindthis is the teaching of the Buddhas.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The essence of Buddha's teaching is simple yet profound: avoid harmful actions, pursue virtuous deeds, and purify the mind.

buddhist.text: Enduring patience is the highest asceticism, Nirvana is the supreme. He is not a true monk who harms others, nor a true renunciate who causes suffering.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Patience is the pinnacle of spiritual discipline, and Nirvana the ultimate goal. True monks and renunciates embody non-harming and compassion.

buddhist.text: Not speaking evil, not harming others, restraint in what one takes, moderation in food, living in solitude, and devotion to high thinkingthis is the teaching of the Buddhas.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The Buddha's path includes right speech, nonviolence, honesty, moderation, solitude, and contemplation. These form the basis of a mindful life.

buddhist.text: There is no satisfying lusts, even with a rain of gold. He who knows that sensual desires are short-lived and cause pain, is wise.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: No amount of indulgence can quench desire. Wisdom lies in recognizing the fleeting and painful nature of sensual cravings.

buddhist.text: Even in heavenly pleasures, the wise find no joy. The disciple of the Buddha delights in the destruction of craving.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: True disciples are not enchanted even by divine pleasures. Their joy comes from the end of craving itself.

buddhist.text: Driven by fear, people seek refuge in mountains, forests, shrines. But these are not safe havens.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: People run to external places for protection, but such refuges are ultimately unreliable and cannot protect one from suffering.

buddhist.text: He who has gone for refuge to the Buddha, to the Dhamma, and to the Sangha, sees the Four Noble Truths with wisdom.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Those who truly take refuge in the Buddha, his teachings, and the community, gain insight into the Four Noble Truthsthe core of the path to liberation.

buddhist.text: Suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the Eightfold Paththese are the Four Noble Truths.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The Four Noble Truths are: suffering, its cause (craving), its end (nirvana), and the path (Eightfold Path) that leads to its cessation.

buddhist.text: This refuge is secure, this is the best refuge: having gone to it, a man is delivered from all pain.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Taking true refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha leads to liberation from all sufferingthis is the ultimate safe haven.

buddhist.text: A man of true merit, understanding the Noble Truths, sees clearly and follows the Path of peace.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The person who deeply grasps the Noble Truths is wise and walks the tranquil path that leads to liberation.

buddhist.text: A good man is hard to find, he is not born everywhere. Wherever such a wise man is born, that family prospers.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Truly good and wise individuals are rare. When one is born, their presence brings blessings to their entire family.

buddhist.text: Blessed is the birth of the Buddhas, blessed is the teaching of the Dhamma, blessed is the harmony in the Sangha, blessed is the devotion of those who live in peace.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Great fortune lies in the arising of Buddhas, the sharing of Dhamma, unity in the monastic community, and the sincere devotion of peaceful seekers.

buddhist.text: He who reveres those worthy of reverence, be they Buddhas or disciples, who are free from passion and fearhis merit cannot be measured.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Immeasurable merit arises for those who show reverence to the enlightenedbe they Buddhas or discipleswho have transcended desire and fear.

buddhist.text: One who honors those who live by the Dharma and have realized Nirvana gains merit that cannot be taken away.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: By respecting and honoring those who have realized the Dharma and attained Nirvana, one earns eternal spiritual merit.

buddhist.text: Let us live happily, then, not hating those who hate us! Among men who hate us, let us dwell free from hatred!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Even when surrounded by hostility, one can choose to live in peace and love. The path of happiness is to be free from hatred regardless of others' anger.

buddhist.text: Let us live happily, then, free from ailments among the ailing! Among men who are ailing, let us dwell free from ailment!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: True happiness comes from inner well-being. Even in a world filled with suffering and illness, one can live with a healthy mind and heart.

buddhist.text: Let us live happily, then, free from greed among the greedy! Among men who are greedy, let us dwell free from greed!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: In a world driven by desire, true joy lies in renouncing greed and living simply. Happiness comes from contentment, not accumulation.

buddhist.text: Let us live happily, then, though we call nothing our own! We shall be like the bright gods, feeding on happiness!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Possessions do not define joy. By detaching from ownership and craving, one can live like radiant beings who are nourished by bliss itself.

buddhist.text: Victory breeds hatred, for the conquered is unhappy. He who has given up both victory and defeat, he is contented and happy.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Winning leads to pride, losing to sorrow. True peace comes from letting go of both, and finding joy beyond competition or ego.

buddhist.text: There is no fire like passion, there is no shark like hatred, there is no snare like folly, there is no torrent like craving.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Desire, hatred, ignorance, and craving are the greatest dangers in lifemore destructive than any natural force. Mastering them leads to liberation.

buddhist.text: The fault of others is easily perceived, but that of oneself is difficult to perceive. A man winnows his neighbor's faults like chaff, but his own he hides, as a cheat hides bad dice.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: People are quick to see the flaws of others while ignoring their own. Wisdom begins with self-awareness and honest introspection.

buddhist.text: If a man looks after the faults of others, and is always inclined to find fault, his own passions will grow, and he is far from the destruction of passions.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Criticizing others without working on oneself fuels inner turmoil. The path to peace lies in correcting one's own mind, not judging others.

buddhist.text: There is no path through the air, a man is not a Samana by outward acts. The world delights in vanity, the Tathagatas are free from vanity.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Spiritual realization is not found through appearances or superficial acts. True sages go beyond worldly vanity and live in inner truth.

buddhist.text: He who takes refuge in the Dhamma, who follows the way of righteousness, who sees clearly, will be at peace.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: One who sincerely embraces the Dharma and lives in harmony with truth will find inner peace and clarity.

buddhist.text: He who lives for pleasure and has not overcome desires, he who is controlled by cravings, will not reach the path of wisdom.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A life driven by desire clouds judgment and keeps one far from true insight. Wisdom requires mastery over cravings.

buddhist.text: The wise find joy in detachment, the foolish chase pleasure like the weak follow mirages. The wise seek the calm shore beyond.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Fools are captivated by fleeting illusions, while the wise pursue lasting peace through detachment from worldly desires.

buddhist.text: He who harms the innocent, who delights in the pain of others, soon finds himself caught in his own trap of suffering.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Those who take joy in causing harm are planting the seeds of their own suffering. Karma returns with precision.

buddhist.text: One is not wise simply because they talk a lot. But if they are calm, loving, and fearless, they are truly wise.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Wisdom is not measured by words, but by one's charactercalmness, compassion, and courage reveal true understanding.

buddhist.text: The one who abandons anger, pride, and deceit, and lives ethically and wisely, that person shines like the moon.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Letting go of harmful emotions and living with virtue causes a person to shine with purity and grace, like the full moon.

buddhist.text: The fool who knows he is a fool is wise at least in that. But the fool who thinks himself wise is truly a fool.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Recognizing one's ignorance is the beginning of wisdom. Delusion lies in believing oneself wise when one is not.

buddhist.text: A fool who associates with the wise may benefit for a time, but it is like a spoon tasting soupit does not know the flavor.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Being near wisdom is not enough, without understanding or applying it, one remains unchangedjust as a spoon cannot taste what it holds.

buddhist.text: A wise person, even with little learning, lives rightly and mindfullylike the tongue tasting soup, they know its flavor.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: True wisdom lies in applying what one knows. Even modest knowledge leads to great clarity when lived with awareness.

buddhist.text: The fool lives in pain, craving what he does not have and grieving over what he loses. He suffers both ways.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Fools are trapped in desire and attachment, always yearning or mourning. This cycle is a source of constant suffering.

buddhist.text: Envy and greed destroy the fool. His thirst grows, and with it, his suffering.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The more the fool envies and desires, the more they suffer. Greed is a flame that feeds its own pain.

buddhist.text: He who seeks his own happiness by inflicting pain on others, is entangled in hatred and cannot be free.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Causing harm to others for personal gain traps one in hatred and suffering. True happiness cannot be built on the pain of others.

buddhist.text: What ought to be done is neglected, what ought not to be done is done, the desires of the unruly and thoughtless are always increasing.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: When people neglect their duties and indulge in harmful actions, desires grow unchecked. Lack of mindfulness leads to chaos.

buddhist.text: But they whose minds are fully awakened, who do not delight in sensual pleasures, are ever mindful and attain unshaken peace.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Those who are spiritually awakened, detached from craving, and remain mindful experience deep and stable inner peace.

buddhist.text: Having cut the bonds of attachment, the wise renounce the world, and abandoning desire and craving, they find joy in solitude.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Liberation begins with severing attachments. The wise give up worldly longing and find peace and joy in detachment and solitude.

buddhist.text: He who controls his rising anger like a charioteer controls a swerving chariot, him I call a true charioteer. Others merely hold the reins.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Mastery over anger is a sign of true strength. Unlike those who appear in control, the truly disciplined guide themselves with precision and wisdom.

buddhist.text: Let a man overcome anger by love, let him overcome evil by good, let him overcome the greedy by liberality, the liar by truth!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse presents a foundational principle of Buddhist ethics: to counter negative states and actions not with similar negativity, but with their virtuous opposites. It instructs one to overcome **anger with love**, **evil with good**, **greed with generosity**, and **deceit with truthfulness**. This approach emphasizes active compassion and integrity as the path to peace and overcoming adverse influences [1].

buddhist.text: Speak the truth, do not yield to anger, give, if thou art asked for little, by these three steps thou wilt go near the gods.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse outlines a simple yet profound path to spiritual elevation. It advises practicing **truthfulness**, **controlling anger** (not yielding to it), and demonstrating **generosity** even when asked for only a small amount. These three practices, according to the teaching, lead one closer to a divine or enlightened state [1].

buddhist.text: The sages who injure nobody, and who always control their body, they will go to the unchangeable place (Nirvana), where, if they have gone, they will suffer no more.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Here, the attributes of a sage are defined by their **non-harming nature** towards any being and their consistent **control over their physical actions**. Such individuals are destined for 'Nirvana,' which is described as an 'unchangeable place' where suffering ceases entirely. This highlights the importance of ethical conduct and self-mastery as direct routes to ultimate liberation [1].

buddhist.text: Those who are ever watchful, who study day and night, and who strive after Nirvana, their passions will come to an end.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse emphasizes the **diligence and persistent effort** required on the spiritual path. It states that individuals who maintain constant 'watchfulness' (mindfulness), dedicate themselves to 'study' (understanding the Dharma) ceaselessly, and actively 'strive after Nirvana' will ultimately achieve the eradication of their passions, leading to inner freedom [1].

buddhist.text: This is an old saying, O Atula, this is not only of to-day: `They blame him who sits silent, they blame him who speaks much, they also blame him who says little, there is no one on earth who is not blamed.'
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse offers a realistic perspective on human nature and social interaction. It conveys the timeless truth that **criticism is inevitable**, regardless of how one behaveswhether silent, verbose, or concise. The underlying message is to not be overly disturbed by external blame, as no one can entirely escape it [2].

buddhist.text: There never was, there never will be, nor is there now, a man who is always blamed, or a man who is always praised.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Building on the previous verse, this reinforces the **impermanence and relativity of human judgment**. It asserts that no individual has ever, or will ever, experience constant blame or perpetual praise. This insight can help cultivate equanimity towards both criticism and commendation [2].

buddhist.text: But he whom those who discriminate praise continually day after day, as without blemish, wise, rich in knowledge and virtue, who would dare to blame him, like a coin made of gold from the Gambu river? Even the gods praise him, he is praised even by Brahman.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse describes the characteristics of a truly praiseworthy person: one who is **without fault, wise, and abundant in both knowledge and virtue**. Their inherent worth is so undeniable that even discerning individuals, gods, and even Brahman (a high deity) offer continuous praise. This illustrates that genuine inner purity and wisdom naturally command respect and admiration [2].

buddhist.text: But he whom those who discriminate praise continually day after day, as without blemish, wise, rich in knowledge and virtue, who would dare to blame him, like a coin made of gold from the Gambu river? Even the gods praise him, he is praised even by Brahman.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse is a continuation of the previous one, emphasizing the **unquestionable moral and spiritual standing** of a person characterized by blamelessness, wisdom, and virtue. Such a person's integrity is likened to pure gold, implying that their inherent goodness makes them beyond reproach, even in the eyes of divine beings [2].

buddhist.text: Beware of bodily anger, and control thy body! Leave the sins of the body, and with thy body practise virtue!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This is the first in a series of verses on controlling actions born of anger, starting with the **physical body**. It serves as a warning against allowing anger to manifest through physical acts, urging one to abandon harmful bodily deeds and instead use the body as an instrument for virtuous conduct [3].

buddhist.text: Beware of the anger of the tongue, and control thy tongue! Leave the sins of the tongue, and practise virtue with thy tongue!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Following the previous verse, this focuses on **controlling angry speech**. It advises guarding against verbal expressions of anger and abandoning harmful or untruthful words. Instead, one should use their speech for virtuous purposes, such as speaking truth, kindness, and beneficial words [3].

buddhist.text: Beware of the anger of the mind, and control thy mind! Leave the sins of the mind, and practise virtue with thy mind!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse completes the triad of body, speech, and mind, emphasizing the **control of angry thoughts and mental states**. It highlights that true spiritual purity begins at the mental level, urging one to abandon unwholesome thoughts and cultivate virtuous ones within the mind itself [3].

buddhist.text: The wise who control their body, who control their tongue, the wise who control their mind, are indeed well controlled.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse summarizes the preceding three, defining true **self-control as mastery over one's body, speech, and mind**. It asserts that individuals who have achieved this comprehensive control are indeed considered 'well controlled' or truly disciplined, embodying wisdom [3].

buddhist.text: Thou art now like a sear leaf, the messengers of death (Yama) have come near to thee, thou standest at the door of thy departure, and thou hast no provision for thy journey.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse serves as a stark and urgent reminder of **mortality and the brevity of life**. It likens a person near death to a 'sear leaf,' signifying decay and impending departure. The absence of 'provision for thy journey' implies a lack of spiritual preparation or merit for the inevitable transition beyond this life [4].

buddhist.text: Make thyself an island, work hard, be wise! When thy impurities are blown away, and thou art free from guilt, thou wilt enter into the heavenly world of the elect (Ariya).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse provides a clear directive for spiritual liberation: cultivate **self-reliance** ('make thyself an island'), engage in **diligent effort** ('work hard'), and attain **wisdom**. The result of purifying oneself from 'impurities' and 'guilt' is entry into a higher spiritual state, metaphorically described as the 'heavenly world of the elect (Ariya)' [4].

buddhist.text: Thy life has come to an end, thou art come near to death (Yama), there is no resting-place for thee on the road, and thou hast no provision for thy journey.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse reiterates the theme of impending mortality from verse 235, emphasizing the **finality and urgency of preparing for death**. It underscores the idea that without spiritual 'provision,' there is no comfort or secure 'resting-place' on the journey beyond life [4].

buddhist.text: Make thyself an island, work hard, be wise! When thy impurities are blown away, and thou art free from guilt, thou wilt not enter again into birth and decay.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse repeats the exhortation from verse 236, reinforcing the importance of **self-effort, diligence, and wisdom** in eliminating 'impurities' and 'guilt.' The ultimate reward for such purification is liberation from the cycle of 'birth and decay' (samsara), a key goal in Buddhist teaching [5].

buddhist.text: Let a wise man blow off the impurities of his self, as a smith blows off the impurities of silver one by one, little by little, and from time to time.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse offers a practical metaphor for the process of self-purification. It likens the wise person's effort to a **smith refining silver**, suggesting that the removal of 'impurities' from oneself is a **gradual, meticulous, and continuous process**, requiring consistent effort over time [5].

buddhist.text: As the impurity which springs from the iron, when it springs from it, destroys it, thus do a transgressor's own works lead him to the evil path.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse uses the analogy of **rust forming on iron and ultimately destroying it** to illustrate how one's own negative actions or 'impurities' (transgressions) inevitably lead to one's own downfall or 'evil path.' It highlights the self-destructive nature of unwholesome deeds [5].

buddhist.text: The taint of prayers is non-repetition, the taint of houses, non-repair, the taint of the body is sloth, the taint of a watchman, thoughtlessness.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse identifies various forms of 'taint' or neglect. It suggests that a prayer loses its efficacy without repetition, a house decays without repair, the body suffers from sloth, and a watchman fails in duty due to thoughtlessness. This illustrates how **lack of diligence and mindfulness leads to deterioration** in various aspects of life and practice [6].

buddhist.text: Bad conduct is the taint of woman, greediness the taint of a benefactor, tainted are all evil ways in this world and in the next.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Continuing the theme of 'taint,' this verse specifies certain actions and qualities as defilements. It states that 'bad conduct' is a blemish, and 'greediness' taints even a benefactor. The broader message is that **all 'evil ways' or unwholesome actions lead to negative consequences** in both the present life and the future [6].

buddhist.text: But there is a taint worse than all taints-ignorance is the greatest taint. O mendicants! throw off that taint, and become taintless!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse identifies the **supreme 'taint' as ignorance**, proclaiming it to be worse than all others. It delivers a direct exhortation to mendicants to 'throw off' this fundamental defilement in order to achieve a state of complete purity and liberation. This highlights ignorance (avidya) as the root cause of suffering in Buddhist thought [6].

buddhist.text: Life is easy to live for a man who is without shame, a crow hero, a mischief-maker, an insulting, bold, and wretched fellow.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse describes the superficial 'ease' of life for those who lack moral conscience. It characterizes individuals who are **shameless, aggressive ('crow hero'), mischievous, insulting, bold, and wretched** as finding life seemingly effortless. This implies that such an 'easy' life is devoid of ethical concern and ultimately leads to negative consequences [6].

buddhist.text: But life is hard to live for a modest man, who always looks for what is pure, who is disinterested, quiet, spotless, and intelligent.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse contrasts with the previous one, explaining that a life dedicated to **virtue and spiritual purity** is often perceived as 'hard to live.' It describes the modest, pure-seeking, disinterested, quiet, spotless, and intelligent person, whose path involves conscious effort and discipline, differentiating it from the unexamined 'easy' life of the morally lax [7].

buddhist.text: He who destroys life, who speaks untruth, who in this world takes what is not given him, who goes to another man's wife,
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse begins a list of **unwholesome actions**, specifying: taking life, speaking falsehoods, stealing (taking what is not given), and adultery (going to another man's wife). These actions are considered serious transgressions that lead to negative karmic results [7].

buddhist.text: And the man who gives himself to drinking intoxicating liquors, he, even in this world, digs up his own root.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse continues the list of harmful actions, adding **consuming intoxicating liquors**. It states that anyone who engages in these unwholesome deeds 'digs up his own root,' a powerful metaphor indicating that such actions lead to **self-destruction and undermine one's own well-being** in this very life [7].

buddhist.text: O man, know this, that the unrestrained are in a bad state, take care that greediness and vice do not bring thee to grief for a long time!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse serves as a direct warning against a **lack of self-restraint**. It emphasizes that 'unrestrained' individuals are in a detrimental condition and cautions against the long-term suffering caused by 'greediness and vice.' It underscores the importance of mindful conduct to avoid prolonged grief [7].

buddhist.text: The world gives according to their faith or according to their pleasure: if a man frets about the food and the drink given to others, he will find no rest either by day or by night.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse comments on the nature of giving and receiving, and the mind's attachment to it. It highlights that if one harbors **envy or discontent ('frets') over the provisions given to others**, regardless of the generosity or pleasure with which they were given, that individual will suffer from a persistent lack of inner peace [8].

buddhist.text: He in whom that feeling is destroyed, and taken out with the very root, finds rest by day and by night.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: As an antidote to the previous verse, this states that a person who has completely **eradicated the 'feeling' of fretting or envy over others' gains**, 'taken out with the very root,' will experience **uninterrupted peace of mind**, day and night. This emphasizes the liberation that comes from overcoming comparison and attachment [8].

buddhist.text: There is no fire like passion, there is no shark like hatred, there is no snare like folly, there is no torrent like greed.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This powerful verse uses vivid metaphors to describe the destructive nature of key defilements. **Passion (lust/craving) is likened to a burning fire**, **hatred to a predatory shark**, **folly (ignorance/delusion) to an inescapable snare**, and **greed to an overwhelming torrent**. Each metaphor illustrates the profound danger and suffering these unwholesome states inflict [8].

buddhist.text: The fault of others is easily perceived, but that of oneself is difficult to perceive, a man winnows his neighbour's faults like chaff, but his own fault he hides, as a cheat hides the bad die from the gambler.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse points out a common human tendency: the **ease with which one perceives the flaws of others contrasted with the difficulty of recognizing one's own**. It uses the vivid analogy of winnowing chaff (separating waste from grain) for others' faults, and a cheat hiding a 'bad die' (a loaded dice) to represent the self-deception in concealing one's own imperfections [8].

buddhist.text: If a man looks after the faults of others, and is always inclined to be offended, his own passions will grow, and he is far from the destruction of passions.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse explains the detrimental effect of dwelling on the imperfections of others. It states that constantly focusing on 'faults of others' and being 'inclined to be offended' will only cause one's **own passions to increase**, thereby moving one further away from the goal of eradicating defilements [9].

buddhist.text: There is no path through the air, a man is not a Samana by outward acts. The world delights in vanity, the Tathagatas (the Buddhas) are free from vanity.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse makes two important points: firstly, true spiritual attainment ('Samana,' an ascetic) is **not achieved through external or superficial acts** (like magical powers, 'path through the air'). Secondly, it contrasts the general human inclination to 'delight in vanity' with the **Buddhas (Tathagatas), who are entirely free from vanity**, highlighting their profound detachment and wisdom [9].

buddhist.text: There is no path through the air, a man is not a Samana by outward acts. No creatures are eternal, but the awakened (Buddha) are never shaken.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse reiterates that outward displays are not indicative of being a 'Samana.' It also introduces the fundamental Buddhist truth of **impermanence, stating that 'no creatures are eternal.'** In contrast, the 'awakened' (Buddhas) are described as 'never shaken,' implying their unshakable inner peace and stability born of profound realization, despite the impermanence of all else [9].

buddhist.text: A man is not just if he carries a matter by violence, no, he who distinguishes both right and wrong, who is learned and leads others, not by violence, but by law and equity, and who is guarded by the law and intelligent, he is called just.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse defines true justice, rejecting the use of 'violence' as a means. Instead, it asserts that a 'just' person is one who can **discern between right and wrong**, is 'learned,' and guides others through **'law and equity'** rather than force. Such a person is also 'guarded by the law' and 'intelligent,' emphasizing a foundation in wisdom and ethical principles [9].

buddhist.text: A man is not just if he carries a matter by violence, no, he who distinguishes both right and wrong, who is learned and leads others, not by violence, but by law and equity, and who is guarded by the law and intelligent, he is called just.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse is a repetition of 256, underscoring the core definition of a 'just' individual. It emphasizes that justice is fundamentally about **moral discernment, knowledge, and leadership guided by principle (law and equity)**, rather than brute force. The 'just' person is characterized by wisdom and adherence to ethical standards [9].

buddhist.text: A man is not learned because he talks much, he who is patient, free from hatred and fear, he is called learned.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse redefines 'learnedness' beyond mere eloquence or extensive speech. It asserts that true learning is demonstrated through **inner qualities such as patience, freedom from hatred, and freedom from fear**. This shifts the focus from intellectual accumulation to profound emotional and mental mastery [10].

buddhist.text: A man is not a supporter of the law because he talks much, even if a man has learnt little, but sees the law bodily, he is a supporter of the law, a man who never neglects the law.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse distinguishes between theoretical knowledge and practical embodiment of the Dharma ('the law'). It states that one is not a true 'supporter of the law' simply by speaking about it. Instead, someone who **'sees the law bodily' (lives it, embodies it)**, even if they have little formal learning, is the true adherent and never neglects its principles [10].

buddhist.text: A man is not an elder because his head is grey, his age may be ripe, but he is called `Old-in-vain.'
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse challenges the notion that physical age automatically confers wisdom or the status of an 'elder.' It suggests that if an individual's life has not been accompanied by spiritual growth or accumulated wisdom, then their advanced age is merely physical, earning them the title 'Old-in-vain' [10].

buddhist.text: He in whom there is truth, virtue, love, restraint, moderation, he who is free from impurity and is wise, he is called an elder.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse provides the true criteria for being recognized as an 'elder.' It states that a person is called an elder based on their **inner qualities**: possession of 'truth, virtue, love, restraint, moderation,' freedom from 'impurity,' and true 'wisdom.' This underscores that genuine respect and spiritual authority are earned through ethical and intellectual development [10].

buddhist.text: An envious greedy, dishonest man does not become respectable by means of much talking only, or by the beauty of his complexion.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse reinforces the idea that **external appearances or verbal prowess do not equate to true respectability**. It explicitly states that individuals characterized by envy, greed, and dishonesty cannot achieve genuine respect, regardless of their eloquence or physical attractiveness. Inner character is paramount [11].

buddhist.text: He in whom all this is destroyed, and taken out with the very root, he, when freed from hatred and wise, is called respectable.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse defines true respectability as the complete **eradication of negative traits ('all this'), including hatred, at their very root**. A person who has achieved this liberation and cultivated wisdom is genuinely 'respectable,' emphasizing that inner transformation is the basis for true esteem [11].

buddhist.text: Not by tonsure does an undisciplined man who speaks falsehood become a Samana, can a man be a Samana who is still held captive by desire and greediness?
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse questions the authenticity of someone claiming to be a 'Samana' (ascetic) based solely on outward signs like 'tonsure' (shaving the head). It asserts that an undisciplined person who speaks falsely, or who remains enslaved by 'desire and greediness,' cannot genuinely be considered a Samana, highlighting the **importance of inner transformation over external symbols** [11].

buddhist.text: He who always quiets the evil, whether small or large, he is called a Samana (a quiet man), because he has quieted all evil.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse provides a profound definition of a 'Samana' (quiet man or ascetic). It states that a true Samana is one who **consistently and effectively 'quiets' or overcomes all forms of 'evil,'** regardless of their magnitude. The designation 'Samana' thus reflects a state of deep inner peace achieved through the complete eradication of unwholesome states [11].

buddhist.text: A man is not a mendicant (Bhikshu) simply because he asks others for alms, he who adopts the whole law is a Bhikshu, not he who only begs.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse clarifies the authentic meaning of 'Bhikshu' (mendicant). It asserts that merely 'asking others for alms' does not define a true Bhikshu. Instead, the true Bhikshu is one who **fully embraces and practices 'the whole law' (Dharma)**, indicating that commitment to the spiritual path, not just its external rituals, is what constitutes a real mendicant [12].

buddhist.text: He who is above good and evil, who is chaste, who with knowledge passes through the world, he indeed is called a Bhikshu.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse offers a deeper definition of a 'Bhikshu,' highlighting key spiritual qualities. A true Bhikshu is one who transcends conventional dualities ('above good and evil' in the sense of being free from attachment to either), is 'chaste' (pure), and navigates the world with profound 'knowledge' (wisdom). This describes a liberated individual who is untouched by worldly concerns [12].

buddhist.text: A man is not a Muni because he observes silence (mona, i.e. mauna), if he is foolish and ignorant, but the wise who, taking the balance, chooses the good and avoids evil, he is a Muni, and is a Muni thereby, he who in this world weighs both sides is called a Muni.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse distinguishes true wisdom from mere ascetic practice. It states that observing 'silence' (mona) does not make one a 'Muni' (sage) if one remains foolish and ignorant. Instead, a genuine Muni is characterized by their **wisdom to discern and choose 'good' while avoiding 'evil'**, constantly 'weighing both sides' of actions and their consequences. This emphasizes discernment and ethical conduct as hallmarks of a sage [12].

buddhist.text: A man is not a Muni because he observes silence (mona, i.e. mauna), if he is foolish and ignorant, but the wise who, taking the balance, chooses the good and avoids evil, he is a Muni, and is a Muni thereby, he who in this world weighs both sides is called a Muni.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse is a direct repetition of verse 268, reinforcing the profound distinction between outward signs of asceticism and true inner wisdom. It stresses that being a 'Muni' (sage) is not about physical 'silence' if coupled with foolishness, but about the **wise and discerning choice of good over evil**, demonstrating a careful consideration of all aspects of existence [12].

buddhist.text: A man is not an elect (Ariya) because he injures living creatures, because he has pity on all living creatures, therefore is a man called Ariya.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse clarifies the meaning of 'Ariya' (the elect or noble one). It explicitly states that causing 'injury to living creatures' disqualifies one from this title. Instead, a person is called an Ariya precisely **because they possess 'pity' or compassion for 'all living creatures'**. This highlights compassion as a defining characteristic of true nobility in Buddhism [13].

buddhist.text: Not only by discipline and vows, not only by much learning, not by entering into a trance, not by sleeping alone, do I earn the happiness of release which no worldling can know. Bhikshu, be not confident as long as thou hast not attained the extinction of desires.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse explains that genuine 'happiness of release' (liberation/Nirvana) cannot be achieved solely through external practices like 'discipline and vows,' extensive 'learning,' meditative 'trance,' or solitary living. It cautions a 'Bhikshu' (mendicant) against false confidence, asserting that true liberation comes only with the **complete 'extinction of desires'** [13].

buddhist.text: Not only by discipline and vows, not only by much learning, not by entering into a trance, not by sleeping alone, do I earn the happiness of release which no worldling can know. Bhikshu, be not confident as long as thou hast not attained the extinction of desires.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse is a repetition of 271, strongly emphasizing that the ultimate 'happiness of release,' unattainable by ordinary worldly individuals, is not merely the result of superficial adherence to 'discipline and vows,' intellectual 'learning,' or even advanced meditative states like 'trance' or solitary living. The core message for a 'Bhikshu' is to **remain vigilant until the root cause of suffering, the 'extinction of desires,' is fully achieved** [13].

buddhist.text: The best of ways is the eightfold, the best of truths the four words, the best of virtues passionlessness, the best of men he who has eyes to see.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse succinctly encapsulates core Buddhist teachings. It identifies the **Noble Eightfold Path** as the supreme method for liberation, the **Four Noble Truths** as the most profound insights, and **passionlessness (detachment from cravings)** as the highest virtue. The 'best of men' is described as one who 'has eyes to see,' signifying profound wisdom and spiritual insight [13].

buddhist.text: This is the way, there is no other that leads to the purifying of intelligence. Go on this way! Everything else is the deceit of Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) (the tempter).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse forcefully asserts the **singular efficacy of the prescribed path for purifying the mind ('intelligence')**. It presents this path as the only one leading to liberation and warns that all other perceived alternatives are illusions or 'deceit' orchestrated by 'Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion),' the personification of temptation and delusion [14].

buddhist.text: If you go on this way, you will make an end of pain! The way was preached by me, when I had understood the removal of the thorns (in the flesh).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse provides a powerful assurance: following the path will lead to the **complete cessation of 'pain' (suffering)**. The speaker, implicitly the Buddha, affirms that this 'way' was taught only after his own direct and profound understanding of how to 'remove the thorns'metaphorically, the painful attachments and defilements inherent in existence [14].

buddhist.text: You yourself must make an effort. The Tathagatas (Buddhas) are only preachers. The thoughtful who enter the way are freed from the bondage of Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse emphasizes the principle of **self-reliance in spiritual practice**. It clarifies that while 'Tathagatas' (Buddhas) illuminate the path as 'preachers,' the actual effort and responsibility for liberation rests with the individual. Those who 'thoughtfully enter the way' through their own diligence are freed from the 'bondage of Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion)' (temptation and suffering) [14].

buddhist.text: `All created things perish,' he who knows and sees this becomes passive in pain, this is the way to purity.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse introduces the profound insight into **impermanence: 'All created things perish.'** Understanding and deeply seeing this truth leads to a state of 'passive in pain,' meaning one becomes detached and equanimous towards suffering because one understands its transient nature. This realization is presented as a fundamental step towards purity [14].

buddhist.text: `All created things are grief and pain,' he who knows and sees this becomes passive in pain, this is the way that leads to purity.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse reiterates a core truth: **'All created things are grief and pain.'** The profound understanding and insight into this inherent suffering leads to equanimity, allowing one to become 'passive in pain.' This acceptance and detachment are presented as the essential path to purity [15].

buddhist.text: `All forms are unreal,' he who knows and sees this becomes passive in pain, this is the way that leads to purity.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse emphasizes the characteristic of **insubstantiality or 'unreality' (anatta) of 'all forms.'** When one truly 'knows and sees' this truth, it fosters a detachment that makes one 'passive in pain.' This understanding of non-self and emptiness is presented as a crucial aspect of the path leading to purity [15].

buddhist.text: He who does not rouse himself when it is time to rise, who, though young and strong, is full of sloth, whose will and thought are weak, that lazy and idle man will never find the way to knowledge.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse serves as a strong admonition against **laziness and lack of spiritual effort**. It warns that even those who are physically capable ('young and strong') but are filled with 'sloth,' 'weak will,' and 'weak thought' will be unable to discover the path to true knowledge (enlightenment) [15].

buddhist.text: Watching his speech, well restrained in mind, let a man never commit any wrong with his body! Let a man but keep these three roads of action clear, and he will achieve the way which is taught by the wise.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse outlines the three crucial 'roads of action' for ethical conduct: **mindful speech, a restrained mind, and avoiding bodily wrongdoings**. It asserts that by keeping these three aspects of one's conduct pure and clear, an individual will successfully follow the path taught by wise beings (the Buddha and his enlightened disciples) [15].

buddhist.text: Through zeal knowledge is gotten, through lack of zeal knowledge is lost, let a man who knows this double path of gain and loss thus place himself that knowledge may grow.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse highlights the **critical role of 'zeal' (diligence or energetic effort)** in the acquisition and preservation of knowledge. It presents a 'double path': knowledge is gained through zeal and lost through its absence. Therefore, one who understands this principle should strategically position themselves to foster continuous growth in knowledge [16].

buddhist.text: Cut down the whole forest (of lust), not a tree only! Danger comes out of the forest (of lust). When you have cut down both the forest (of lust) and its undergrowth, then, Bhikshus, you will be rid of the forest and free!
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse uses a powerful metaphor: the 'forest' represents 'lust' or craving, a dense entanglement of desires. It urges for the **complete eradication of lust**, not just a superficial removal of individual desires ('not a tree only'). By eliminating both the 'forest' and its 'undergrowth' (root causes), the Bhikshu will achieve true freedom from its dangers and attain liberation [16].

buddhist.text: So long as the love of man towards women, even the smallest, is not destroyed, so long is his mind in bondage, as the calf that drinks milk is to its mother.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse illustrates the **binding nature of even subtle attachments**, using the example of 'love of man towards women' as a metaphor for craving in general. It explains that as long as this attachment, however slight, persists, the mind remains in 'bondage,' just as a calf is bound to its mother by its need for milk. It underscores the need for complete detachment for true liberation [16].

buddhist.text: Cut out the love of self, like an autumn lotus, with thy hand! Cherish the road of peace. Nirvana has been shown by Sugata (Buddha).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse instructs to **actively eliminate 'the love of self' (self-clinging)**, likening it to effortlessly plucking an 'autumn lotus.' It then advises to 'cherish the road of peace,' which refers to the path leading to tranquility and ultimate liberation. It concludes by reminding that 'Nirvana' (the state of perfect peace and freedom) has already been revealed by 'Sugata' (a title for the Buddha) [17].

buddhist.text: `Here I shall dwell in the rain, here in winter and summer,' thus the fool meditates, and does not think of his death.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse describes the short-sightedness and delusion of a 'fool.' Such a person is preoccupied with planning for worldly comforts and seasonal changes, but conspicuously **'does not think of his death'**the ultimate inevitable reality. This highlights the foolishness of ignoring impermanence [17].

buddhist.text: Death comes and carries off that man, praised for his children and flocks, his mind distracted, as a flood carries off a sleeping village.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse vividly illustrates the **sudden and unavoidable nature of death**. It depicts how death overtakes individuals who are absorbed in worldly praise and attachments (children, flocks), with their minds 'distracted,' likening it to an irresistible flood sweeping away an unsuspecting village. It's a call to wakefulness regarding mortality [17].

buddhist.text: Sons are no help, nor a father, nor relations, there is no help from kinsfolk for one whom death has seized.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse emphasizes the **ultimate solitude in the face of death**. It states that in the grip of death, no worldly relationshipsneither children, nor a father, nor other relativescan offer true assistance or salvation. This underscores the need for individual spiritual preparation [17].

buddhist.text: A wise and good man who knows the meaning of this, should quickly clear the way that leads to Nirvana.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse offers a directive for those who have understood the impermanence of life and the futility of worldly attachments (as described in previous verses). It urges a **'wise and good man' to 'quickly clear the way' to Nirvana**, implying that this profound understanding should motivate immediate and diligent spiritual practice towards liberation [18].

buddhist.text: If by leaving a small pleasure one sees a great pleasure, let a wise man leave the small pleasure, and look to the great.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse provides guidance on making choices based on long-term spiritual benefit. It advises that if foregoing a 'small pleasure' (worldly or transient gratification) leads to the realization of a 'great pleasure' (the lasting happiness of liberation or spiritual attainment), then a **wise person should readily choose the greater benefit** [18].

buddhist.text: He who, by causing pain to others, wishes to obtain pleasure for himself, he, entangled in the bonds of hatred, will never be free from hatred.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse highlights the karmic consequence of selfish actions. It states that an individual who seeks personal pleasure by 'causing pain to others' will remain **'entangled in the bonds of hatred'** and will never achieve freedom from it. This emphasizes that harming others perpetuates one's own suffering [18].

buddhist.text: What ought to be done is neglected, what ought not to be done is done, the desires of unruly, thoughtless people are always increasing.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse describes the characteristic behavior of undisciplined and heedless individuals. They **neglect wholesome actions ('what ought to be done') and engage in unwholesome ones ('what ought not to be done')**. This pattern of conduct, it warns, leads to a continuous increase in their desires, trapping them further in the cycle of craving [18].

buddhist.text: But they whose whole watchfulness is always directed to their body, who do not follow what ought not to be done, and who steadfastly do what ought to be done, the desires of such watchful and wise people will come to an end.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse contrasts with the previous one, describing the disciplined path. It highlights individuals whose mindfulness ('watchfulness') is constantly directed towards their body (a key meditation object), who actively avoid unwholesome actions and steadfastly perform wholesome ones. For such **'watchful and wise people,' their desires will ultimately cease**, leading to liberation [19].

buddhist.text: A true Brahmana goes scatheless, though he have killed father and mother, and two valiant kings, though he has destroyed a kingdom with all its subjects.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse uses powerful, symbolic language to describe the ultimate liberation of a 'true Brahmana' (an enlightened one). The seemingly extreme actions (killing father and mother, kings, destroying a kingdom) are understood metaphorically in Buddhist tradition. 'Father and mother' can represent craving and conceit, or ignorance and craving, or the roots of existence, 'kings' and 'kingdom' can represent powerful defilements or attachments. The verse implies that for one who has eradicated these deep-seated roots of suffering and attachment, they have transcended the cycle of karma and remain **'scatheless' or unburdened by worldly consequences** [19].

buddhist.text: A true Brahmana goes scatheless, though he have killed father and mother, and two holy kings, and an eminent man besides.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse is a continuation of the symbolic statement from 294, further emphasizing the profound state of liberation achieved by a 'true Brahmana.' The enumerated acts'killed father and mother, two holy kings, and an eminent man'are to be understood metaphorically as the **complete eradication of the deepest defilements and attachments** (such as craving, ignorance, conceit, and attachment to existence itself). Having severed these roots of suffering, the Brahmana remains 'scatheless,' beyond karmic entanglement [19].

buddhist.text: The disciples of Gotama (Buddha) are always well awake, and their thoughts day and night are always set on Buddha.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse begins a series describing the mindfulness practices of the Buddha's (Gotama's) disciples. It highlights their state of constant 'awakening' and their **unwavering mental focus on the Buddha** himself, reflecting devotion and adherence to his teachings as a central object of contemplation [20].

buddhist.text: The disciples of Gotama are always well awake, and their thoughts day and night are always set on the law.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Continuing the description of the disciples' mindfulness, this verse emphasizes their constant 'awakening' and their **thoughts being perpetually 'set on the law' (Dharma)**. This signifies their continuous contemplation and adherence to the principles and teachings revealed by the Buddha [20].

buddhist.text: The disciples of Gotama are always well awake, and their thoughts day and night are always set on the church.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse completes the 'Triple Gem' of Buddhist refuge (Buddha, Dharma, Sangha). It describes the disciples' continuous 'awakening' and their **thoughts being consistently 'set on the church' (Sangha)**, referring to the community of practitioners. This indicates a deep appreciation for and connection to the spiritual community [20].

buddhist.text: The disciples of Gotama are always well awake, and their thoughts day and night are always set on their body.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse specifies another crucial practice for the Buddha's disciples: constant mindfulness of their 'body.' This 'watchfulness' involves observing the physical form and its processes, which helps cultivate **insight into impermanence, suffering, and non-self**, leading to detachment and liberation [20].

buddhist.text: The disciples of Gotama are always well awake, and their mind day and night always delights in compassion.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse highlights the cultivation of a wholesome mental state among the Buddha's disciples. It states that their awakened minds continually **'delight in compassion'** (metta or karuna) day and night, indicating that boundless goodwill and empathy are central to their spiritual practice [21].

buddhist.text: The disciples of Gotama are always well awake, and their mind day and night always delights in meditation.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse emphasizes the continuous practice of meditation among the Buddha's disciples. It states that their awakened minds **'delight in meditation'** persistently, day and night. This underscores the role of sustained meditative practice in cultivating mental clarity, serenity, and insight [21].

buddhist.text: It is hard to leave the world (to become a friar), it is hard to enjoy the world, hard is the monastery, painful are the houses, painful it is to dwell with equals (to share everything in common) and the itinerant mendicant is beset with pain. Therefore let no man be an itinerant mendicant and he will not be beset with pain.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse presents a nuanced view of both worldly and monastic life, suggesting that **suffering is inherent in many paths**. It notes the difficulty of both renunciation ('to leave the world') and worldly enjoyment, as well as challenges within monastic life (monastery, common dwelling, itinerancy). The concluding statement, 'Therefore let no man be an itinerant mendicant and he will not be beset with pain,' implies that unless one is fully prepared to endure the inherent difficulties of that specific path, it might be wiser to avoid it to minimize pain [21].

buddhist.text: Whatever place a faithful, virtuous, celebrated, and wealthy man chooses, there he is respected.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse describes the universal respect accorded to an individual possessing an array of positive qualities. It states that a person who is **'faithful, virtuous, celebrated, and wealthy' will command respect** regardless of where they choose to reside. This highlights the value placed on strong character, integrity, and social standing [22].

buddhist.text: Good people shine from afar, like the snowy mountains, bad people are not seen, like arrows shot by night.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse uses a vivid metaphor to contrast the visibility of virtue with the obscurity of vice. **'Good people' are likened to 'snowy mountains' that shine clearly even from a distance**, implying their positive influence and moral clarity are evident. Conversely, 'bad people' are compared to 'arrows shot by night,' unseen and hidden, suggesting their negative actions and character remain concealed or unacknowledged [22].

buddhist.text: He alone who, without ceasing, practises the duty of sitting alone and sleeping alone, he, subduing himself, will rejoice in the destruction of all desires alone, as if living in a forest.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse emphasizes the **importance of solitary practice and self-discipline** for achieving liberation. It states that one who consistently engages in the duty of 'sitting alone and sleeping alone' (symbolizing solitude and detachment), and thereby 'subduing himself,' will find joy in the 'destruction of all desires.' This profound happiness is likened to the peaceful, unburdened existence of one living alone in a forest [22].

buddhist.text: He who says what is not, goes to hell, he also who, having done a thing, says I have not done it. After death both are equal, they are men with evil deeds in the next world.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse issues a clear warning against **dishonesty and denial of one's actions**. It states that both those who 'say what is not' (lie) and those who deny their past deeds will face negative consequences, metaphorically 'going to hell.' It underscores that such 'evil deeds' have adverse karmic repercussions in the afterlife [23].

buddhist.text: Many men whose shoulders are covered with the yellow gown are ill-conditioned and unrestrained, such evil-doers by their evil deeds go to hell.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse critiques hypocrisy, particularly among those who adopt outward religious symbols but lack inner virtue. It warns that many who wear the 'yellow gown' (the robes of a mendicant) are 'ill-conditioned and unrestrained.' Such individuals, despite their appearance, will face negative karmic results ('go to hell') due to their 'evil deeds,' emphasizing that **actions, not outward garb, determine spiritual destiny** [23].

buddhist.text: Better it would be to swallow a heated iron ball, like flaring fire, than that a bad unrestrained fellow should live on the charity of the land.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse powerfully conveys the **gravity of unworthiness in receiving charity while lacking discipline**. It suggests that it would be preferable to endure extreme physical suffering ('swallow a heated iron ball') than for an 'unrestrained fellow' to live off the generosity of others without genuine spiritual commitment. This underscores the high ethical standards expected of those in monastic life [23].

buddhist.text: Four things does a wreckless man gain who covets his neighbour's wife-a bad reputation, an uncomfortable bed, thirdly, punishment, and lastly, hell.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse lists the direct negative consequences that a 'reckless man' incurs by **coveting another's wife (adultery)**. These consequences are: a **'bad reputation,' 'an uncomfortable bed'** (implying personal distress or unhappy relationships), **'punishment'** (legal or societal), and ultimately, **'hell'** (karmic retribution in the next life). It serves as a stern warning against this transgression [24].

buddhist.text: There is bad reputation, and the evil way (to hell), there is the short pleasure of the frightened in the arms of the frightened, and the king imposes heavy punishment, therefore let no man think of his neighbour's wife.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse elaborates on the negative repercussions of adultery. It highlights the lasting consequences of a 'bad reputation' and the 'evil way' (leading to hell). It also emphasizes the **futility and fear associated with illicit pleasure** ('short pleasure of the frightened in the arms of the frightened') and the severe 'punishment' imposed by secular authorities. The strong concluding admonition serves to deter such actions [24].

buddhist.text: As a grass-blade, if badly grasped, cuts the arm, badly-practised asceticism leads to hell.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse uses a cautionary analogy to highlight the danger of improper spiritual practice. Just as a 'grass-blade' (specifically, the sharp Kusa grass) can injure if held incorrectly, similarly, **'badly-practised asceticism' (or any spiritual effort performed without proper understanding or sincerity) can lead to detrimental outcomes**, metaphorically 'hell,' rather than liberation [24].

buddhist.text: An act carelessly performed, a broken vow, and hesitating obedience to discipline, all this brings no great reward.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse emphasizes the importance of **diligence, commitment, and wholeheartedness in spiritual practice**. It states that actions performed 'carelessly,' vows that are 'broken,' or obedience to 'discipline' that is 'hesitating' will not yield significant spiritual benefits or 'great reward.' True progress requires unwavering dedication [24].

buddhist.text: If anything is to be done, let a man do it, let him attack it vigorously! A careless pilgrim only scatters the dust of his passions more widely.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse advocates for **energetic and decisive action** in performing wholesome deeds. It stresses that one should pursue good actions 'vigorously.' Conversely, a 'careless pilgrim' who lacks diligence in their spiritual journey will only exacerbate their 'passions,' hindering their progress rather than achieving purification [25].

buddhist.text: An evil deed is better left undone, for a man repents of it afterwards, a good deed is better done, for having done it, one does not repent.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse provides a straightforward moral principle based on the consequence of actions. It advises that **'an evil deed is better left undone' because it leads to future regret**. Conversely, 'a good deed is better done' because it brings lasting satisfaction and no cause for repentance, reinforcing the wisdom of ethical conduct [25].

buddhist.text: Like a well-guarded frontier fort, with defences within and without, so let a man guard himself. Not a moment should escape, for they who allow the right moment to pass, suffer pain when they are in hell.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse urges **constant vigilance and self-protection in one's spiritual life**, using the metaphor of a 'well-guarded frontier fort.' One must defend oneself internally and externally against defilements. The admonition 'Not a moment should escape' highlights the urgency of practice, warning that those who miss opportunities for spiritual effort ('allow the right moment to pass') will face profound suffering, metaphorically 'in hell' [25].

buddhist.text: They who are ashamed of what they ought not to be ashamed of, and are not ashamed of what they ought to be ashamed of, such men, embracing false doctrines enter the evil path.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse critiques a fundamental moral inversion: individuals who feel **shame for virtuous or harmless things and yet lack shame for genuinely shameful or harmful actions**. Such a distorted moral compass, born from 'embracing false doctrines,' inevitably leads them onto an 'evil path,' away from wholesome conduct and liberation [25].

buddhist.text: They who fear when they ought not to fear, and fear not when they ought to fear, such men, embracing false doctrines, enter the evil path.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse continues the theme of moral distortion, focusing on the appropriate application of fear. It describes those who **fear things that are not truly dangerous (like spiritual practice or truth) but do not fear what is genuinely harmful (like unwholesome actions or their consequences)**. This misdirection of fear, arising from 'false doctrines,' leads individuals down an 'evil path' [26].

buddhist.text: They who forbid when there is nothing to be forbidden, and forbid not when there is something to be forbidden, such men, embracing false doctrines, enter the evil path.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse extends the critique of distorted moral judgment to the act of forbidding. It describes those who **prohibit things that are not harmful or even beneficial, while failing to prohibit actions that are genuinely destructive**. This faulty discernment, rooted in 'false doctrines,' steers individuals onto an 'evil path' [26].

buddhist.text: They who know what is forbidden as forbidden, and what is not forbidden as not forbidden, such men, embracing the true doctrine, enter the good path.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse provides the positive counterpoint to the previous three, defining true moral discernment. It states that individuals who **correctly understand what is truly 'forbidden' (unwholesome) and what is 'not forbidden' (wholesome)** are the ones who, by 'embracing the true doctrine,' embark upon and remain on the 'good path' to spiritual progress [26].

buddhist.text: Silently shall I endure abuse as the elephant in battle endures the arrow sent from the bow: for the world is ill-natured.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse advocates for **patient and resolute endurance in the face of verbal abuse**. It uses the powerful simile of a battle elephant stoically withstanding arrows to illustrate the strength required to bear insults silently, acknowledging that the world often manifests an 'ill-natured' or hostile disposition [27].

buddhist.text: They lead a tamed elephant to battle, the king mounts a tamed elephant, the tamed is the best among men, he who silently endures abuse.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse praises the virtue of self-mastery through the analogy of a 'tamed elephant.' Just as a disciplined elephant is valuable in battle or for a king, so too is the **'tamed' individual considered 'the best among men,' particularly one who can 'silently endures abuse'**. This highlights inner control and resilience as supreme qualities [27].

buddhist.text: Mules are good, if tamed, and noble Sindhu horses, and elephants with large tusks, but he who tames himself is better still.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse makes a comparison between the taming of animals and the taming of oneself. While well-trained animals (mules, Sindhu horses, elephants) are valuable, the verse asserts that the **individual who 'tames himself' is 'better still.'** This emphasizes that self-mastery is a more profound and superior accomplishment than controlling external beings [27].

buddhist.text: For with these animals does no man reach the untrodden country (Nirvana), where a tamed man goes on a tamed animal, viz. on his own well-tamed self.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse explains *why* self-taming is superior. It clarifies that external means, such as relying on powerful animals, cannot lead to the ultimate goal of 'Nirvana' ('the untrodden country'). Instead, the path to liberation is traversed only when **a 'tamed man' progresses on his 'own well-tamed self,'** signifying that inner discipline and self-mastery are the sole vehicles for spiritual journey [27].

buddhist.text: The elephant called Dhanapalaka, his temples running with sap, and difficult to hold, does not eat a morsel when bound, the elephant longs for the elephant grove.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse provides a specific analogy involving the elephant Dhanapalaka, known for its powerful and wild nature. Even when restrained and suffering, the elephant refuses food, instead **longing for its natural habitat, the 'elephant grove.'** This can be interpreted as a metaphor for the mind, which, when confined by suffering or attachments, yearns for its natural, unconstrained state of freedom [28].

buddhist.text: If a man becomes fat and a great eater, if he is sleepy and rolls himself about, that fool, like a hog fed on wash, is born again and again.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse criticizes **excessive indulgence and sloth**, describing a 'fool' who is consumed by gluttony and idleness. Such a person, likened to a 'hog fed on wash,' is destined to be 'born again and again,' signifying continued entanglement in the cycle of samsara (rebirth) due to their heedless and undisciplined lifestyle [28].

buddhist.text: This mind of mine went formerly wandering about as it liked, as it listed, as it pleased, but I shall now hold it in thoroughly, as the rider who holds the hook holds in the furious elephant.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse is a powerful declaration of intent to **master the unruly mind**. The speaker acknowledges that their mind previously 'wandered about as it liked,' but now resolves to 'hold it in thoroughly.' This self-control is vividly compared to a rider using a 'hook' to forcefully tame a 'furious elephant,' emphasizing the discipline required to rein in one's thoughts [28].

buddhist.text: Be not thoughtless, watch your thoughts! Draw yourself out of the evil way, like an elephant sunk in mud.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse delivers a direct exhortation to cultivate **mindfulness and to actively extricate oneself from unwholesome paths**. It warns against 'thoughtlessness' and urges one to 'watch your thoughts.' The analogy of an 'elephant sunk in mud' powerfully illustrates the effort needed to pull oneself free from harmful mental states and actions [29].

buddhist.text: If a man find a prudent companion who walks with him, is wise, and lives soberly, he may walk with him, overcoming all dangers, happy, but considerate.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse highlights the **benefit of a good spiritual companion**. It advises that if one finds a 'prudent companion' who is 'wise' and 'lives soberly,' one should walk with them. Such companionship can help overcome dangers, foster happiness, and promote thoughtfulness on the path [29].

buddhist.text: If a man find no prudent companion who walks with him, is wise, and lives soberly, let him walk alone, like a king who has left his conquered country behind-like an elephant in the forest.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse provides an alternative path for those unable to find a suitable spiritual companion. It advises to **'walk alone,'** likening this solitude to a 'king who has left his conquered country behind' (having achieved his goal and being unburdened by further attachments) or 'an elephant in the forest' (self-sufficient and independent). This promotes self-reliance and contentment in solitude when wise companionship is absent [29].

buddhist.text: It is better to live alone, there is no companionship with a fool, let a man walk alone, let him commit no sin, with few wishes, like an elephant in the forest.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse explicitly states the preference for **solitary living over association with 'fools,'** emphasizing that such companionship offers no benefit. It encourages an individual to 'walk alone,' avoid 'sin,' and cultivate 'few wishes,' drawing parallels once again with the independent and unburdened existence of an 'elephant in the forest' [29].

buddhist.text: If an occasion arises, friends are pleasant, enjoyment is pleasant, whatever be the cause, a good work is pleasant in the hour of death, the giving up of all grief is pleasant.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse lists various sources of 'pleasantness' or happiness in life. It notes the joy of **friends when available, the general pleasure of enjoyment, and the specific satisfaction of performing 'good work,' especially as one approaches death**. The highest pleasantness, however, is identified as the **'giving up of all grief,'** signifying the ultimate liberation from suffering [30].

buddhist.text: Pleasant in the world is the state of a mother, pleasant the state of a father, pleasant the state of a Samana, pleasant the state of a Brahmana.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse identifies specific roles and states that bring pleasantness or joy within the world. It recognizes the positive and nurturing states associated with **'mother' and 'father,'** and extends this to the spiritually fulfilling states of a **'Samana' (ascetic) and a 'Brahmana' (enlightened one or spiritual practitioner)**, highlighting the inherent goodness and peace in these respected positions [30].

buddhist.text: Pleasant is virtue lasting to old age, pleasant is a faith firmly rooted, pleasant is attainment of intelligence, pleasant is avoiding of sins.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse continues the theme of what brings lasting pleasantness and happiness. It specifies that **enduring 'virtue' into old age, a 'firmly rooted faith' (in the Dharma), the acquisition of 'intelligence' (wisdom), and the diligent 'avoiding of sins'** are all sources of profound and sustainable contentment. These are presented as spiritual attainments that contribute to a truly pleasant life [30].

buddhist.text: The thirst of a thoughtless man grows like a creeper, he runs from life to life, like a monkey seeking fruit in the forest.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse introduces the concept of **'thirst' (tanh, or craving)**, explaining how it proliferates in a 'thoughtless' or heedless person, much like a rapidly growing 'creeper.' This unbridled craving causes individuals to be reborn 'from life to life,' restless and unsatisfied, akin to a 'monkey seeking fruit in the forest' [31].

buddhist.text: Whomsoever this fierce thirst overcomes, full of poison, in this world, his sufferings increase like the abounding Birana grass.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse describes the destructive power of 'fierce thirst.' It warns that when an individual is overcome by this craving, which is depicted as being 'full of poison,' their **sufferings will proliferate and intensify**, much like the rapid and pervasive growth of 'Birana grass' [31].

buddhist.text: He who overcomes this fierce thirst, difficult to be conquered in this world, sufferings fall off from him, like water-drops from a lotus leaf.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse offers the solution to the pervasive problem of 'thirst.' It states that even though this craving is 'difficult to be conquered,' the individual who successfully **overcomes it will experience the complete cessation of suffering**. This liberation is beautifully illustrated by the image of 'water-drops from a lotus leaf,' which simply roll off without clinging [31].

buddhist.text: This salutary word I tell you, `Do ye, as many as are here assembled, dig up the root of thirst, as he who wants the sweet-scented Usira root must dig up the Birana grass, that Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion) (the tempter) may not crush you again and again, as the stream crushes the reeds.'
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse delivers a direct and urgent exhortation to a gathered audience. It instructs them to **'dig up the root of thirst' (craving)**, using the analogy of a person digging up unwanted 'Birana grass' to find the valuable Usira root.
