The purpose is to prevent 'Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion)' (the tempter, representing death and delusion) from continuously overwhelming them, just as a powerful 'stream crushes the reeds.' This emphasizes the critical importance of eradicating craving for liberation [31].

buddhist.text: As a tree, even though it has been cut down, is firm so long as its root is safe, and grows again, thus, unless the feeders of thirst are destroyed, the pain (of life) will return again and again.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse employs the metaphor of a tree to explain the persistence of suffering. It states that just as a tree will regrow if its root remains intact, so too will the **'pain (of life)' repeatedly return unless the underlying 'feeders of thirst' (the causes of craving) are completely destroyed**. This highlights the necessity of addressing the root causes of suffering for genuine liberation [32].

buddhist.text: He whose thirst running towards pleasure is exceeding strong in the thirty-six channels, the waves will carry away that misguided man, viz. his desires which are set on passion.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse describes the overwhelming power of intense craving for pleasure. It states that when a person's 'thirst' is excessively strong and spread across numerous 'channels' (referring to the senses and their objects, multiplied in various combinations, representing the vast scope of craving), they will be **swept away by the 'waves' of their own passionate desires**, like a 'misguided man' adrift in a torrent [32].

buddhist.text: The channels run everywhere, the creeper (of passion) stands sprouting, if you see the creeper springing up, cut its root by means of knowledge.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse reiterates the pervasive nature of desires, referring to them as 'channels' running everywhere and 'the creeper (of passion)' continuously sprouting. It provides a crucial instruction: upon recognizing the emergence of this 'creeper,' one must **'cut its root by means of knowledge,'** indicating that wisdom and insight are the essential tools for eradicating craving [32].

buddhist.text: A creature's pleasures are extravagant and luxurious, sunk in lust and looking for pleasure, men undergo (again and again) birth and decay.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse describes the human condition characterized by an insatiable pursuit of 'extravagant and luxurious' pleasures. It warns that individuals who are **'sunk in lust and looking for pleasure' will continuously experience the cycle of 'birth and decay'** (samsara), highlighting that attachment to sensory gratification perpetuates suffering and rebirth [33].

buddhist.text: Men, driven on by thirst, run about like a snared hare, held in fetters and bonds, they undergo pain for a long time, again and again.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse uses the poignant image of a **'snared hare' to depict individuals 'driven on by thirst' (craving)**. Like the trapped animal, people are held by 'fetters and bonds' (of attachment and delusion), causing them to 'undergo pain for a long time, again and again' in the cycle of existence [33].

buddhist.text: Men, driven on by thirst, run about like a snared hare, let therefore the mendicant drive out thirst, by striving after passionlessness for himself.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse repeats the analogy of the 'snared hare' to illustrate how craving drives humans. It then offers a direct instruction for mendicants: to **actively 'drive out thirst' by 'striving after passionlessness' (detachment) for themselves**. This emphasizes the individual effort required to liberate oneself from craving and its associated suffering [33].

buddhist.text: He who having got rid of the forest (of lust) (i.e. after having reached Nirvana) gives himself over to forest-life (i.e. to lust), and who, when removed from the forest (i.e. from lust), runs to the forest (i.e. to lust), look at that man! though free, he runs into bondage.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse serves as a stern warning against spiritual backsliding. It describes someone who has conceptually or partially 'got rid of the forest (of lust)' (achieved some liberation or understanding), but then paradoxically 'gives himself over to forest-life' (returns to lust). This person, despite having tasted freedom, **chooses to re-enter 'bondage' by succumbing to old desires**, highlighting the ease with which one can fall back into unwholesome patterns [33].

buddhist.text: Wise people do not call that a strong fetter which is made of iron, wood, or hemp, far stronger is the care for precious stones and rings, for sons and a wife.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse explains that for 'wise people,' true 'fetters' are not physical bonds like 'iron, wood, or hemp.' Instead, the **far stronger and more binding 'fetters' are the attachments and 'care' for worldly possessions** ('precious stones and rings') and, even more profoundly, for loved ones ('sons and a wife'). This highlights the spiritual danger of emotional clinging [34].

buddhist.text: That fetter wise people call strong which drags down, yields, but is difficult to undo, after having cut this at last, people leave the world, free from cares, and leaving desires and pleasures behind.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse continues the explanation of true 'fetters' from the previous verse. It defines the 'strong' fetter as that which spiritually 'drags down' and is hard to break. The verse concludes that only by **'cutting this' true fetter (deep-seated attachments and desires) can individuals truly 'leave the world' (of suffering), becoming 'free from cares'** and transcending all worldly 'desires and pleasures' [34].

buddhist.text: Those who are slaves to passions, run down with the stream (of desires), as a spider runs down the web which he has made himself, when they have cut this, at last, wise people leave the world free from cares, leaving all affection behind.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse uses the metaphor of a **spider caught in its own web to describe those 'slaves to passions.'** Just as the spider creates its own trap, individuals driven by desires create their own suffering, flowing 'down with the stream (of desires).' However, it states that 'wise people,' by 'cutting this' self-made web of attachment, are eventually able to 'leave the world' of suffering, achieving freedom from all 'cares' and 'affection' (emotional attachment) [34].

buddhist.text: Give up what is before, give up what is behind, give up what is in the middle, when thou goest to the other shore of existence, if thy mind is altogether free, thou wilt not again enter into birth and decay.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse provides a comprehensive instruction for achieving complete liberation. 'Giving up what is before' refers to past attachments, 'what is behind' refers to future expectations, and 'what is in the middle' refers to present cravings. By **letting go of attachments to past, present, and future, and achieving a mind 'altogether free,'** one ensures they 'wilt not again enter into birth and decay' (the cycle of samsara), reaching the 'other shore of existence' [35].

buddhist.text: If a man is tossed about by doubts, full of strong passions, and yearning only for what is delightful, his thirst will grow more and more, and he will indeed make his fetters strong.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse describes how a mind afflicted by **'doubts,' 'strong passions,' and a pervasive 'yearning for what is delightful'** leads to a detrimental cycle. These states cause one's 'thirst' (craving) to continuously 'grow more and more,' thereby strengthening the 'fetters' (attachments) that bind one to suffering [35].

buddhist.text: If a man delights in quieting doubts, and, always reflecting, dwells on what is not delightful (the impurity of the body, &c.), he certainly will remove, nay, he will cut the fetter of Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse offers the antidote to the conditions described in the previous verse. It states that an individual who **'delights in quieting doubts'** (cultivating certainty in the Dharma) and consistently 'dwells on what is not delightful' (meditating on the unattractive or impermanent nature of the body and other phenomena) will effectively **'cut the fetter of Mara (the embodiment of desire and illusion)'** (break free from the bonds of temptation and suffering) [35].

buddhist.text: He who has reached the consummation, who does not tremble, who is without thirst and without sin, he has broken all the thorns of life: this will be his last body.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse describes the characteristics of a fully liberated being, one who has 'reached the consummation' (of the spiritual path). Such an individual is **fearless ('does not tremble'), free from 'thirst' (craving), and 'without sin' (all defilements)**. They have 'broken all the thorns of life' (overcome all obstacles and pains), indicating that this present existence will be their 'last body,' meaning no more rebirths [36].

buddhist.text: He who is without thirst and without affection, who understands the words and their interpretation, who knows the order of letters (those which are before and which are after), he has received his last body, he is called the great sage, the great man.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse further describes the qualities of a 'great sage' or 'great man' who has achieved ultimate liberation. Such a person is **free from 'thirst' (craving) and 'affection' (attachment)**. Their wisdom extends to a profound understanding of the 'words and their interpretation' (the Dharma) and the 'order of letters' (the full scope and depth of knowledge). Having attained this, they are said to have 'received his last body,' signifying no further rebirths [36].

buddhist.text: `I have conquered all, I know all, in all conditions of life I am free from taint, I have left all, and through the destruction of thirst I am free, having learnt myself, whom shall I teach?'
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse presents a profound declaration of enlightenment, likely spoken by the Buddha or another fully awakened being. It expresses **complete victory over all defilements ('conquered all'), omniscient knowledge ('know all'), and total freedom from 'taint' in all situations**. The speaker asserts liberation achieved 'through the destruction of thirst,' and the rhetorical question 'whom shall I teach?' implies that having perfected oneself, there is no one left to learn from, but rather a capacity to teach others [36, 37].

buddhist.text: The gift of the law exceeds all gifts, the sweetness of the law exceeds all sweetness, the delight in the law exceeds all delights, the extinction of thirst overcomes all pain.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse extols the supreme value of the Dharma ('the law'). It states that the **'gift of the law' is superior to all other gifts, its 'sweetness' surpasses all others, and 'delight in the law' is greater than all worldly pleasures**. The ultimate triumph, it concludes, is that the **'extinction of thirst' (craving) effectively 'overcomes all pain'** (suffering), highlighting the Dharma as the path to ultimate freedom [37].

buddhist.text: Pleasures destroy the foolish, if they look not for the other shore, the foolish by his thirst for pleasures destroys himself, as if he were his own enemy.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse warns about the deceptive nature of worldly pleasures. It states that 'pleasures destroy the foolish' because they fail to look for 'the other shore' (Nirvana or liberation). The 'foolish' person, driven by their 'thirst for pleasures,' inadvertently **causes their own destruction, acting 'as if he were his own enemy,'** underscoring the self-inflicted harm of attachment [37].

buddhist.text: The fields are damaged by weeds, mankind is damaged by passion: therefore a gift bestowed on the passionless brings great reward.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse uses an agricultural analogy to illustrate a spiritual truth. Just as 'fields are damaged by weeds,' so too is 'mankind damaged by passion' (kleshas, defilements). The conclusion is that **generosity ('a gift bestowed') towards those who are 'passionless' (free from defilements) yields 'great reward,'** signifying the high merit of supporting enlightened beings [37].

buddhist.text: The fields are damaged by weeds, mankind is damaged by hatred: therefore a gift bestowed on those who do not hate brings great reward.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse reiterates the analogy from 356, specifying 'hatred' as a destructive force that damages humanity. Consequently, it states that **offering 'a gift bestowed on those who do not hate' yields 'great reward,'** emphasizing the merit in supporting individuals who have transcended animosity [38].

buddhist.text: The fields are damaged by weeds, mankind is damaged by vanity: therefore a gift bestowed on those who are free from vanity brings great reward.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Continuing the pattern, this verse identifies 'vanity' as a harmful weed that afflicts humanity. It states that **generosity towards 'those who are free from vanity' brings 'great reward,'** highlighting the spiritual benefit of supporting humble and unpretentious beings [38].

buddhist.text: The fields are damaged by weeds, mankind is damaged by lust: therefore a gift bestowed on those who are free from lust brings great reward.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Completing this series of analogies, this verse points to 'lust' as a pervasive defilement that damages mankind. It concludes that **offering 'a gift bestowed on those who are free from lust' results in 'great reward,'** emphasizing the positive karmic impact of supporting those who have overcome sensual craving [38].

buddhist.text: Restraint in the eye is good, good is restraint in the ear, in the nose restraint is good, good is restraint in the tongue.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse begins a section on **sense restraint**, emphasizing the importance of discipline over the five physical senses: **eye, ear, nose, and tongue**. It states that such 'restraint' is beneficial, implying that controlling the input from these senses helps prevent defilements and maintains mental purity [38, 39].

buddhist.text: In the body restraint is good, good is restraint in speech, in thought restraint is good, good is restraint in all things. A Bhikshu, restrained in all things, is freed from all pain.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse expands the concept of restraint beyond the senses to encompass **body, speech, and thought**. It declares that 'restraint in all things' is beneficial. For a 'Bhikshu' (mendicant), achieving such comprehensive self-control leads to ultimate liberation, making them 'freed from all pain' or suffering [39].

buddhist.text: He who controls his hand, he who controls his feet, he who controls his speech, he who is well controlled, he who delights inwardly, who is collected, who is solitary and content, him they call Bhikshu.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse provides a comprehensive definition of a true 'Bhikshu' (mendicant). It describes them not just by external control over their 'hand,' 'feet,' and 'speech,' but also by profound inner qualities: being 'well controlled' overall, experiencing **'inward delight,' maintaining collectedness (mindfulness), embracing solitude, and being truly 'content.'** These are the hallmarks of a genuine renunciant [39].

buddhist.text: The Bhikshu who controls his mouth, who speaks wisely and calmly, who teaches the meaning and the law, his word is sweet.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse focuses specifically on the **virtue of speech for a Bhikshu**. It states that a mendicant who 'controls his mouth,' speaks 'wisely and calmly,' and is able to 'teach the meaning and the law' (Dharma) will have 'sweet' words. This implies that their communication is not only pleasant but also profound and beneficial, reflecting their inner wisdom [39].

buddhist.text: He who dwells in the law, delights in the law, meditates on the law, follows the law, that Bhikshu will never fall away from the true law.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse describes the deep engagement with the Dharma ('the law') that ensures a Bhikshu's steadfastness. It states that one who **'dwells in the law' (lives by it), 'delights in the law' (finds joy in it), 'meditates on the law' (contemplates its truths), and 'follows the law' (practices its precepts)** will remain firmly on the path and 'never fall away from the true law' [40].

buddhist.text: Let him not despise what he has received, nor ever envy others: a mendicant who envies others does not obtain peace of mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: This verse offers crucial advice for mendicants on cultivating inner peace. It instructs them to **avoid despising their meager provisions and, more importantly, to never 'envy others.'** The verse explicitly states that a mendicant who harbors envy 'does not obtain peace of mind,' highlighting the corrosive effect of comparison and dissatisfaction on one's inner tranquility [40].
